2016|dead-url=no|last2=Spencer|first2=Susan|location=New York City, New York|author-link2=Susan Spencer|df=mdy-all}} ===John R. MacDougall=== [[File:Fort Lauderdale Skyline 7.jpg|thumb|left|[[Fort Lauderdale, Florida|Fort Lauderdale]], where MacDougall was raised]] John R. MacDougall was born in [[Elmhurst, Illinois]]; a western suburb of [[Chicago]]. He is the youngest of five children of building contractor Robert MacDougall and his wife Thelma, a homemaker. Shortly after his father's retirement in 1970, the family moved to Florida. He spent his childhood years tinkering with cars and CB radios. MacDougall was brought up in [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida|Fort Lauderdale]], where he was educated at [[American Heritage School (Plantation, Florida)|American Heritage School]]. After two years of studying in a management engineering program at [[Worcester Polytechnic Institute]], MacDougall abandoned his studies and found employment installing satellite dishes in [[Ocala, Florida|Ocala]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/229382970/?terms=Captain+Midnight|title=Capt. Midnight Recalls His One-night Stand (Will He Ever Top The Experience Of A Lifetime? Or Recover From It, For That Matter?)|last=Stiteler|first=Rowland|date=November 30, 1986|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|access-date=September 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921144523/https://www.newspapers.com/image/229382970/?terms=Captain+Midnight|archive-date=September 21, 2017|dead-url=no|page=10 & 155–160|subscription=yes|via=Newspapers.com|df=mdy-all}} In 1983, he opened the satellite dealership MacDougall Electronics in Ocala. The company initially turned a healthy profit, but following the scrambling of HBO's signal on January 15, 1986, its turnover declined. Consequently, he reduced his expenses where possible and in the same month was offered a part-time job at the Central Florida [[Ground station#Telecommunications port|Teleport]] uplink station (which uplinked services to satellites) as an operations engineer to help him pay his bills.{{sfn|Wright|2012|p=130–139}} As he was not receiving any customers, MacDougall pulled all company advertising and saved money by switching off his [[air conditioning]]. He became increasingly reclusive during this period, watching television and reading magazines. MacDougall later said of the experience: "I have been watching the great American dream slip from my grasp." At 12:49 a.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Standard Time]] (EST) on April 20,{{Cite journal|date=July 28, 1986|title='Captain Midnight' unmasked|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-BC/BC-1986/BC-1986-07-28.pdf|journal=[[Broadcasting & Cable|Broadcasting]]|volume=111|issue=4|pages=90–91|issn=0007-2028|oclc=6318655|access-date=September 29, 2017}} one week before the jamming, MacDougall transmitted a [[Test card|color bar test pattern]] that was superimposed on HBO's signal. This only lasted for a few seconds, and HBO did not investigate the incident as it had occurred during the overnight hours, and as a result very few people had been watching at the time.{{#tag:ref|The April 20 intrusion went unreported to the FCC until after the following week's jamming.|group="n"}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1986-07-23/news/0240090082_1_hbo-macdougall-captain-midnight|title=Ocala Man Dished Up That Warning For HBO|last1=Jean|first1=Charlie|last2=Reidy|first2=Chris|date=July 23, 1986|work=Orlando Sentinel|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521012458/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1986-07-23/news/0240090082_1_hbo-macdougall-captain-midnight|archive-date=May 21, 2014|dead-url=no|accessdate=May 20, 2014|df=mdy-all}} ==Jamming== On April 26, 1986, MacDougall worked at his shop as normal, and closed at 4:00 p.m. EST. After eating dinner, he reported to Central Florida Teleport with one other engineer on duty. The second engineer left at 6:00 p.m., leaving MacDougall to operate the building on his own. MacDougall oversaw the uplink of the movie ''[[Pee-wee's Big Adventure]]'' as part of the evening's programming for the [[pay-per-view]] network People's Choice, which used Central Florida Teleport's facilities.{{sfn|Wright|2012|p=130–139}} After the film ended, he went through his regular routine. Before logging off, MacDougall set up [[SMPTE color bars]] and punched buttons on a Microgen MG-100 [[character generator]] that placed letters on the television screen. He spent a couple of minutes composing his message. MacDougall began his message with a polite greeting as he did not wish to be insulting. He selected the name "Captain Midnight" from a film he had recently seen: ''[[On the Air Live with Captain Midnight]]'' (not associated with the popular [[Captain Midnight|''Captain Midnight'' radio show]] of the 1940s). Described by ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' as "a Reagan-era Robin Hood",{{Cite web|url=https://news.avclub.com/30-years-ago-today-a-disgruntled-floridian-interrupted-1798246645|title=30 years ago today, a disgruntled Floridian interrupted HBO's signal|last=Blevins|first=Joe|date=April 27, 2016|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930175129/https://news.avclub.com/30-years-ago-today-a-disgruntled-floridian-interrupted-1798246645|archive-date=September 30, 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=September 30, 2017}} MacDougall swung the {{Convert|30|ft|m|adj=on}} transmission dish back into its storage position, which aimed it at the location of [[Galaxy 1]], the satellite that carried HBO.{{sfn|Leverette et al.|2009|p=4}} Locating the satellite coordinates was not of great difficulty for MacDougall as frequencies were widely published in manuals and enthusiast magazines. As a protest against the introduction of high fees and scrambling equipment, he transmitted a signal onto the satellite that for four and a half minutes overrode HBO's telecast of the film ''[[The Falcon and the Snowman]]'', which had begun two minutes earlier.{{cite web|url=http://www.signaltonoise.net/library/captmidn.htm|title=The Story of Captain Midnight|work=Signal to Noise|accessdate=August 3, 2007|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070128101239/http://www.signaltonoise.net/library/captmidn.htm|archivedate=January 28, 2007}} The five-line text message printed in white capital letters that appeared on the screens of HBO subscribers across the eastern half of the United States (accounting for more than half of HBO's 14.6 million subscribers at the time), starting at 12:32 a.m. EST (05:32 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]{{#tag:ref|In 1986, the switch from Eastern Standard Time (EST) to Eastern Daylight Time (EDT) occurred on the night of April 26–27, at 2:00 a.m. local time, so the Captain Midnight prank occurred a little less than 1.5 hours before the beginning of EDT.{{cite web|title=Time Change 1986 in the United States|url=https://www.timeanddate.com/time/change/usa?year=1986|work=timeanddate.com|accessdate=September 21, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170922001859/https://www.timeanddate.com/time/change/usa?year=1986|archivedate=September 22, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{sfn|DeFino|2014|p=58}}|group="n"}}) on April 27, appeared as follows:{{sfn|Leverette et al.|2009|p=4}} {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |- |

GOODEVENING HBO
FROM CAPTAIN MIDNIGHT
$12.95/MONTH  ?
NO WAY !
 [SHOWTIME/MOVIE CHANNEL BEWARE!] 
 
|} [[Hughes Communications]] immediately noticed the jamming, and threatened to shut down HBO's satellite signal or alter the satellite's course, with executives believing the hacker was a domestic terrorist.{{sfn|DeFino|2014|p=58}} HBO's technician, working at the company's communication center in [[Hauppauge, New York|Hauppauge, Long Island]], telephoned Hughes Communications, but officials there could not offer an explanation to the jamming, and so he attempted to regain control by increasing the uplink transmission power from 125 watts to 2,000 watts.{{cite journal|last=Goldberg|first=Donald|date=October 1986|title=Captain Midnight, HBO, And World War III|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6OYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA8&dq=Captain+Midnight,+HBO,+And+World+War+III&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjn58CrlLPWAhXDA8AKHVWoD1oQ6AEINTAD#v=onepage&q=Captain%20Midnight&f=false|deadurl=no|journal=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]|volume=XI|issue=VII|pages=26–29|issn=0362-8841|oclc=614361146|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920142850/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6OYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA8&dq=Captain+Midnight,+HBO,+And+World+War+III&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjn58CrlLPWAhXDA8AKHVWoD1oQ6AEINTAD#v=onepage&q=Captain%20Midnight&f=false|archivedate=September 20, 2017|accessdate=September 20, 2017|via=Google Books|df=mdy-all}} This was unsuccessful, as MacDougall increased his power in a control battle that lasted about 90 seconds, during which it was feared that a further power increase would damage the satellite. MacDougall got scared, abandoned his control of the satellite, and went home. The following day, he felt guilty about his actions, but hoped the jamming would not be noticed by anyone not working for HBO. MacDougall was later surprised to see his actions being reported on network television.{{sfn|Wright|2012|p=130–139}} Thus, when he returned to work that night he pretended to have no knowledge about the intrusion, and asked questions about what had happened. MacDougall only told close friends, and had visions about federal agents visiting his home. ==Investigation== Galaxy 1 carried HBO on transponder 23 at a rate of 125 watts, with relay signals sent out at 6,385 [[Hertz#SI multiples|MHz]]. [[Mother Jones (magazine)|''Mother Jones'']] magazine determined that MacDougall could have potentially taken over the signals of three additional satellites. He could have taken control of the network feed of [[CBS]] had he positioned his satellite dish at the [[Telstar 301]] satellite, operated by [[AT&T]], tuned at 6,065 MHz. He also could have taken over the foreign language feed of the [[Voice of America]] network by aiming his satellite dish at 72 degrees west longitude. The final theorized hijacking would have been aiming his satellite dish at 100 degrees west longitude, above the [[Galápagos Islands]], with a frequency setting of 293.375 MHz, thereby jamming the signal of [[United States Navy]] satellite Fleetsatcom 1. The magazine also posited that an amateur hobbyist could hijack the satellites that alerted American military forces to Soviet actions, creating confusion for world leaders and placing the world at risk of nuclear destruction. Although the intrusion caused minor annoyance to viewers, HBO contacted the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) and announced that the hijacker would face prosecution. The commission's chief, Richard Smith, assembled staff in his office for an emergency meeting at the FCC headquarters eight hours after the intrusion to discuss how the culprit should be caught. On April 28 the chairman of HBO, [[Michael J. Fuchs]], wrote to the FCC saying the company had received calls threatening to place Galaxy 1 into a different orbit, but the company was unable to determine whether these were credible threats or not.{{sfn|Williams|2010|p=552–553}} Fuchs's letter additionally urged the commission to use all of its resources to capture the culprit. In the days after the jamming, more than 200 people called the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) to "confess" that they were Captain Midnight. The [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] made indications of its desire to get involved,{{sfn|Wright|2012|p=130–139}} and the FBI was called in to assist the investigation.{{sfn|Williams|2010|p=552–553}} One hundred FCC field offices and monitoring stations across the United States were actively involved in the investigation, with no less than six FCC employees working on the case. Oliver Long, the head engineer of the FCC's Texas field office bureau, oversaw the investigation,{{Cite journal|last=Paikoff|first=Mark|date=Autumn 1987|title=Engineer Profile: Oliver Long of the FCC|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=4Q9LKDGFtswC&pg=PA14&lpg=PA14&dq=Oliver+Long+Captain+Midnight&source=bl&ots=W2kWFsmF9C&sig=x7gU9bxMs85py4ryUuxl8PkRUjQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi43pWNi7bWAhUjLMAKHRwrDuAQ6AEIPTAI#v=onepage&q=Oliver%20Long%20Captain%20Midnight&f=false|deadurl=no|journal=Hispanic Engineer & IT|volume=3|issue=4|pages=14|issn=1058-269X|oclc=962740750|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921193830/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=4Q9LKDGFtswC&pg=PA14&lpg=PA14&dq=Oliver+Long+Captain+Midnight&source=bl&ots=W2kWFsmF9C&sig=x7gU9bxMs85py4ryUuxl8PkRUjQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi43pWNi7bWAhUjLMAKHRwrDuAQ6AEIPTAI#v=onepage&q=Oliver%20Long%20Captain%20Midnight&f=false|archivedate=September 21, 2017|via=Google Books|df=mdy-all}} and the commission assigned agent George Dillon to the case.{{sfn|Wright|2012|p=130–139}} The case first led investigators from the FCC to focus on the [[Dallas–Fort Worth metroplex]],{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-05-04/news/8602010122_1_captain-midnight-dish-antennas-communications-satellite|title=Capt. Midnight Dishes Up Cable Tv Dilemma|last=Clark|first=Kenneth R.|date=May 4, 1986|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|access-date=September 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921193022/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-05-04/news/8602010122_1_captain-midnight-dish-antennas-communications-satellite|archive-date=September 21, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} after an anonymous tip accused an amateur radio operator residing in [[Lewisville, Texas]], of being the culprit.{{cite news|title=Airwaves pirate eludes investigators in U.S.|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1946&dat=19860502&id=v0QlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZagFAAAAIBAJ&pg=951,983433&hl=en|work=[[Montreal Gazette]]|page=D4|date=May 2, 1986|accessdate=September 30, 2017}} Later, the FCC determined which teleport uplink sites out of the 2,000 licensed transmitters in the United States had the capability to override the HBO signal. That narrowed it down to 580 uplink sites that had sufficiently large antennas that had the capability of broadcasting the signal. The manufacturer that produced the character generator graphics model used to generate the typeface on the television screen was also identified after studying footage of the jamming.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1986-07-23/news/mn-21573_1_satellite-dishes|title='Captain Midnight' Enters Plea of Guilty to Video Piracy Count|last=Pagano|first=Penny|date=July 23, 1986|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=September 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160229050007/http://articles.latimes.com/1986-07-23/news/mn-21573_1_satellite-dishes|archive-date=February 29, 2016|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Investigators from the commission obtained copies from an FCC engineer and HBO viewers, as tape machines were not running during the jamming.{{Cite journal|date=July 1986|title=A signal event: on the track of Capt. Midnight - Home Box Office's transmission interrupted|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1511/is_v7/ai_4293600|journal=[[Discover (magazine)|Discover]]|volume=|pages=|issn=0274-7529|oclc=705641511|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050329140604/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1511/is_v7/ai_4293600|archivedate=March 29, 2005|access-date=September 24, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The FCC removed stations from the list of 500 that were inoperative on April 27 or transmitting other material. This method brought the number of potential stations down to twelve. After FCC investigators visited these stations, there were now three prime suspects which included MacDougall. The commission later learned an accountant from [[Wisconsin]] had overheard MacDougall bragging about the jamming at a payphone in a rest area off [[Interstate 75 in Florida|Interstate 75]] in [[Gainesville, Florida|Gainesville]], and obtained a license plate number of a car owned by MacDougall. ==Arrest and prosecution== Prior to the jamming, the FCC warned that anyone interfering with television signals would be harshly dealt with and MacDougall was charged after surrendering to the authorities following media and industry pressure.{{#tag:ref|The FCC is responsible for ensuring nobody interferes with the licensed airwaves transmitted in the United States.|group="n"}}{{sfn|Leverette et al.|2009|p=4}} Investigators from the commission spoke to MacDougall in July (he lost his job at Central Florida Teleport beforehand due to the closure of People's Choice), asking him questions that led him to believe that the commission was aware of the incident. Two FCC agents visited MacDougall's house two weeks later along with U.S. Attorney Lawrence Gentile III, who served MacDougall with a [[subpoena]] to appear in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]]'s U.S. District Court. In their meeting, MacDougall claimed not to have committed any crime. According to MacDougall, Gentile tried to make an agreement that if MacDougall discussed the incident, Gentile would be willing to recommend a small fine and probation to the judge. At that time, MacDougall stated that he started to feel that there was not enough evidence to convict him, and despite continuing to protest his innocence, MacDougall told Gentile he would attend court. MacDougall contacted attorney John Green Jr., who advised him the chances of him winning the case were 70 percent, and that a trial would be risky and costly. He faced being fined up to $100,000 and being sentenced to one year in prison if he was convicted. Furthermore, MacDougall was worried about going before the jury and lying to get himself acquitted. He thus changed his mind and agreed to cooperate fully with the FCC. At his first hearing on the afternoon of July 22, he pleaded guilty to the charge of "illegally operating a satellite uplink transmitter",{{Cite news|url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1986/Captain-Midnight-Arrested-FCC-Says/id-deb8acefb1bf49f38a3a9da149683c20|title=Captain Midnight Arrested, FCC says|last=McCloskey|first=Bill|date=July 22, 1986|access-date=September 21, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921145108/http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1986/Captain-Midnight-Arrested-FCC-Says/id-deb8acefb1bf49f38a3a9da149683c20|archive-date=September 21, 2017|dead-url=no|agency=Associated Press|df=mdy-all}} a violation of [[Title 47 of the United States Code|47 U.S.C.]] [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/47/301 § 301]. Under an agreement with Gentile, MacDougall [[Plea bargaining in the United States|plea bargained]] and received a $5,000 fine, was put on unsupervised probation for one year, and had his amateur radio license suspended for one year.{{sfn|Leverette et al.|2009|p=4}} Later, he was arraigned and freed on a $5,000 [[Bail|bond]]. MacDougall's plea bargain was confirmed at his sentencing by Judge Howard T. Snyder on August 26.{{Cite news|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/micheal-wright-crime-clipping-aug-27-1986-398632/|title=Confessed video pirate 'Captain Midnight' given probation, fine|date=August 27, 1986|work=[[Frederick News-Post]]|access-date=September 21, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=no|agency=Associated Press|issue=219|volume=76|page=D11|subscription=yes|via=Newspaperarchives.com}} Lawyers for Hughes Communications subsequently reviewed the option of taking MacDougall to [[Lawsuit|civil court]], but chose not to take any further action.{{Cite news|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=GPS&sw=w&u=wikipedia&v=2.1&id=GALE%7CA445152109&it=r&asid=bed6c92d919fbd6c7205e8e84e6f45cb|title=A video pirate struck two Chicago television stations, briefly...|date=November 23, 1987|access-date=September 29, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=no|agency=[[United Press International]]|subscription=yes|via=General OneFile}} He was approached for interviews by the major news stations in the United States after his arraignment, but Gentile advised him to not appear on television until his sentencing. MacDougall held a news conference in which he stated he did not contest the rights of cable companies to scramble their programs, but asked the government to allow the marketplace and not corporations to set prices. He revealed he was aware of a year-old magazine that spoke about the type of signal interference he caused, but affirmed the article was not influential on his actions.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1986-07-24/news/0240090208_1_hbo-macdougall-captain-midnight|title=Cable Scrambled Captain Midnight's Dream|last=Runnels|first=Jim|date=July 24, 1986|work=Orlando Sentinel|access-date=September 24, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170924184832/http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1986-07-24/news/0240090208_1_hbo-macdougall-captain-midnight|archive-date=September 24, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ==Reaction== MacDougall's jamming of HBO's satellite signal generated much publicity, and attracted attention from several sectors of society.{{sfn|Wright|2012|p=130–139}} The jamming was described by various press publications as either the first instance of high-technology terrorism, or the most widely watched instance of electronic graffiti in the world.{{Sfn|Himma|2007|p=3–4}} The [[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Communications and Technology|House Communications Subcommittee]] planned to hold meetings concerning the issue of satellite jamming. Members of Congress showed interest, with those coming from states with extensive rural areas showing more sympathy to owners of satellite dishes.{{sfn|Wright|2012|p=130–139}} The hijacking raised concerns over satellite-borne communications: that data transmitted by business and military users would become potential targets. MacDougall's action led to him being immediately regarded as coming close to being a [[folk hero]] amongst disgruntled satellite dish owners who felt unfairly treated.{{Cite journal|last=Scott|first=Karyl|date=July 28, 1986|title=Capt. Midnight surrenders|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Bh0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA1&lpg=PA1&dq=Captain+Midnight+folk+hero&source=bl&ots=56B0hXcgZG&sig=80l3eGR-X0NlsticQ8btkm4bA6c&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiq5YWWp7PWAhVjKcAKHaDHC7sQ6AEIQjAE#v=onepage&q=Captain%20Midnight%20folk%20hero&f=false|deadurl=no|journal=Network World|location=Washington, D.C.|volume=3|pages=2|issn=0887-7661|oclc=123532599|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920142225/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Bh0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA1&lpg=PA1&dq=Captain+Midnight+folk+hero&source=bl&ots=56B0hXcgZG&sig=80l3eGR-X0NlsticQ8btkm4bA6c&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiq5YWWp7PWAhVjKcAKHaDHC7sQ6AEIQjAE#v=onepage&q=Captain%20Midnight%20folk%20hero&f=false|archivedate=September 20, 2017|access-date=September 20, 2017|via=Google Books|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite journal|date=May 5, 1986|title=Captain Midnight' strikes; preempts HBO with message decrying scrambling|url=https://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=GPS&sw=w&u=wikipedia&v=2.1&id=GALE%7CA4233804&it=r&asid=46eb2f487b647ca6c5f19bb66453d552|deadurl=no|journal=Broadcasting|volume=110|pages=71|issn=0007-2028|oclc=6318655|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170920142257/https://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=GPS&sw=w&u=wikipedia&v=2.1&id=GALE%7CA4233804&it=r&asid=46eb2f487b647ca6c5f19bb66453d552|archivedate=September 20, 2017|access-date=September 20, 2017|subscription=yes|via=General OneFile|df=mdy-all}} The Satellite Television Industry Association released a statement denouncing intentional interference, and a spokesperson for the organization called for the offender to be imprisoned. [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] vice president Stephen Schultz dubbed the intrusion as an act of "video terrorism".{{Cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1298&dat=19860607&id=TPpNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=eIsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3985,901383&hl=en|title=Video terrorism|last=Anderson|first=Jack|date=June 7, 1986|work=[[The Free Lance-Star]]|volume=102|number=134|access-date=September 20, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=no|page=10}} ==Aftermath== As a consequence of MacDougall's jamming, and ambiguity about the federal misdemeanor charge made against him under 47 U.S.C. § 301,{{Cite web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/pgay3n/headroom-hacker|title=The Mystery of the Creepiest Television Hack|last=Knittel|first=Chris|last2=Pasternack|first2=Alex|date=November 25, 2013|website=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921144518/https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/pgay3n/headroom-hacker|archive-date=September 21, 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=September 21, 2017|df=mdy-all}} the United States Congress passed the [[Electronic Communications Privacy Act|Electronic Communications Privacy Act of 1986]] ([[Title 18 of the United States Code|18 U.S.C.]] [https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/1367 § 1367]) which made satellite hijacking a [[felony]].{{Cite journal|last=Bloombecker|first=J. J. B.|date=July 1988|title=Captain Midnight and the Space Hackers|url=https://www.ncjrs.gov/App/publications/abstract.aspx?ID=113312|journal=Security Management|volume=32|issue=7|pages=77–79, 82|access-date=September 24, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170924182722/https://www.ncjrs.gov/App/publications/abstract.aspx?ID=113312|archivedate=September 24, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{#tag:ref|The penalty was raised to a fine of $250,000 and/or ten years imprisonment.{{Sfn|Gregg|2013|p=345}}|group="n"}} The FCC subsequently implemented strict requirements that all radio and television transmitters must have an electronic name tag for tracking purposes.{{Sfn|Gregg|2013|p=345}} The [[Automatic Transmitter Identification System (television)|Automatic Transmitter Identification System]] (ATIS) was developed in response to the Captain Midnight jamming incident. It allows satellite operators to quickly identify unauthorized uplink transmissions.{{sfn|United Nations Institute for Disarmament Research|2006|p=36}} In 2009, HBO and Elmer Musser were awarded a [[Technology & Engineering Emmy Award#2009 Awards|Technology & Engineering Emmy Award]] for ATIS.{{cite web|title=61st Annual Technology & Engineering Emmy® Awards Presented at the Mandalay Bay Resort & Casino at the International Consumer Electronics Show at Las Vegas|url=http://emmyonline.org/mediacenter/tech_2k9_winners.html|date=January 7, 2010|publisher=[[National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences]]|accessdate=September 20, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515123456/http://emmyonline.org/mediacenter/tech_2k9_winners.html|archivedate=May 15, 2010|deadurl=yes}} Although HBO has not been targeted since the channel's signal power was increased to make it more difficult for hijackers to intrude, there have been multiple instances of uplink video piracy across the United States.{{Sfn|Himma|2007|p=3–4}} [[Max Headroom broadcast signal intrusion|One such incident happened in November 1987]], when [[WGN-TV]] in Chicago had its transmission briefly interrupted by a man in a [[Max Headroom (character)|Max Headroom]] mask, and that same evening, the signal of [[PBS]] affiliate [[WTTW]] was overridden for one-and-a-half minutes, where the same person [[mooning|mooned]] the viewing audience and had his buttocks struck with a [[Fly-killing device#Flyswatter|fly swatter]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/108010/20151121/max-headroom-tv-hack-anniversary.htm|title=The Curious Case Of The Max Headroom Broadcast, The Biggest TV Hack In History|last=Reich|first=J. E.|date=November 21, 2015|website=Tech Times|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170921001214/http://www.techtimes.com/articles/108010/20151121/max-headroom-tv-hack-anniversary.htm|archive-date=September 21, 2017|dead-url=no|access-date=September 20, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The jamming did not appear to affect HBO's pricing policies in the long-term. Richard Acello, the editor of the home satellite dish magazine ''Satellite TV Week'', stated MacDougall had not been able to achieve folk hero status as had been widely reported in the press:
"He didn't have any No. 1 records written about him or anything like that, and that's always an indication." He added: "The whole event was misunderstood. People took Captain Midnight to be a symbol of frustration people were feeling about scrambling. It made him seem a representative of dish owners, but he was not. There was no way a dish owner could do what he did."{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1986/07/23/cables-captain-midnight-apprehended/5d61712e-60c7-4351-8697-823761120593/|title=Cable's 'Captain Midnight' Apprehended|last=Shales|first=Tom|date=July 23, 1986|work=[[The Washington Post]]|access-date=September 20, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170924183031/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1986/07/23/cables-captain-midnight-apprehended/5d61712e-60c7-4351-8697-823761120593/|archive-date=September 24, 2017|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}}
A group called the Captain Midnight Grassroots Cause was formed, and sold merchandise to help raise money for MacDougall to pay his legal fees.{{sfn|Wright|2012|p=130–139}} MacDougall found the constant media attention difficult to deal with, and was regularly bothered at home. MacDougall shut his office because no work could be undertaken without him being asked about Captain Midnight. {{As of|2011}}, he still resides in Ocala and undertakes consulting work under the MacDougall Electronics name.{{Cite web|url = http://www.networkworld.com/article/2229101/security/captain-midnight---no-regrets--about-jamming-hbo-back-in--86.html|title = Captain Midnight: 'No regrets' about jamming HBO back in '86|date = April 26, 2011|accessdate = July 20, 2015|website = Network World|publisher = |last = McNamara|first = Paul|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150808010011/http://www.networkworld.com/article/2229101/security/captain-midnight---no-regrets--about-jamming-hbo-back-in--86.html|archivedate = August 8, 2015|df = mdy-all}} In a retrospective interview with ''Network World'' in 2011, MacDougall said he did not regret his actions but wished his motivations were more clearly understood:
I do not regret trying to get the message out to corporate America about unfair pricing and restrictive trade practices. That was the impetus for doing what I did; that's the reason I jammed HBO; that's the reason I sent them a polite message. What I do regret is that I was young and fairly naïve in the ways of the media. I didn't grasp the fact that no one understood my motives and that everyone would make assumptions. Had I known that up front I would have been much more fervent in explaining my motivations. I had no animus and I had no malice in my heart.

'''''Comic Art''''' was a magazine, founded and edited by [[Todd Hignite]], which surveyed newspaper comic strips, magazine cartoon panels and [[comic book art]], both historical and contemporary.<ref>{{cite news|title=An Interview With Todd Hignite|url=http://www.comicsreporter.com/index.php/resources/interviews/5349/|accessdate=November 20, 2016|work=The Comics Reporter|date=July 23, 2006}}</ref>
==History and profile== ''Comic Art'' was established in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|title=Comic Art Magazine #1 (Comic Art Magazine, 1)|url=https://www.amazon.com/Comic-Art-Magazine/dp/B003E1C38E|work=Amazon|accessdate=November 20, 2016}}</ref> The first seven issues featured articles on [[Art Spiegelman]], [[Daniel Clowes]], [[Harvey Kurtzman]], [[Crockett Johnson]] and [[Frank King (cartoonist)|Frank King]]. According to critic [[Tom Spurgeon]], "''Comic Art'' is a comics publication that... has chosen to investigate the good and interesting no matter when it's been done."<ref>[http://www.comicsreporter.com/index.php/briefings/cr_reviews/822/ Tom Spurgeon (2005). ''Review of Comic Art #7.''] at ''The Comics Reporter''. Retrieved on November 2, 2006.</ref> Daniel Zimmer was the publication's graphic design and art director for the first seven issues. The eighth and ninth issues were expanded considerably and published annually in book form by Buenaventura Press. Alvin Buenaventura assisted Hignite with editing these two issues, and they were designed and art directed by Jonathan Bennett.
It is not connected with the original [[fanzine]] ''Comic Art'', which was published (beginning in 1960) by [[Maggie Thompson|Maggie and Don Thompson]].

Todd Hignite & Daniel Zimmer (St. Louis, MO) *''Comic Art'' #3, 2003, 80p., M. Todd Hignite & Daniel Zimmer (St. Louis, MO) *''Comic Art'' #4, 2003, 80p., M. Todd Hignite & Daniel Zimmer (St. Louis, MO) *''Comic Art'' #5, 2004, 80p., M. Todd Hignite & Daniel Zimmer (St. Louis, MO) *''Comic Art'' #6, 2004, 80p., M. Todd Hignite & Daniel Zimmer (St. Louis, MO) *''Comic Art'' #7, 2005, 80p., M. Todd Hignite & Daniel Zimmer (St. Louis, MO) *''Comic Art'' #8, 2006, 176p., [[Buenaventura Press]] (Oakland, CA) *''Comic Art'' #9, 2007, 208p., {{ISBN|9780976684862}}, [[Buenaventura Press]] (Oakland, CA)
==Awards== In 2003 the magazine was nominated for both the [[Eisner Awards]] and [[Harvey Awards]], and won the 2004 Harvey Award for ''Best Historical, Biographical, or Journalistic Presentation.''
In 2006, [[Yale University Press]] published a collection of Hignite's "In The Studio" columns in an expanded 320-page hardback, ''In the Studio: Visits with Contemporary Cartoonists'', {{ISBN|0-300-11016-2}}.

The '''Croatian Radio Festival''' (natively '''Hrvatski Radijski Festival''', abbreviation '''HRF''' ) was a [[music festival]] held annually in [[Croatia]] from 1997 to 2009. The festival was first held in 1997 in [[Vodice, Croatia|Vodice]]. It remained in Vodice until 2002, when it was held in [[Šibenik]]. After two years in Šibenik, [[Rijeka]] and [[Požega, Croatia|Požega]] were co-hosts for the 2004 festival. In 2005 and 2006 it was held in [[Trogir]], and in 2007 it was held in [[Hvar]]. In 2008 and 2009 it was held in [[Opatija]]. The festival was cancelled in 2010 due to financial problems and has been never organised since.[http://www.jutarnji.hr/spektakli/ups/juraj-hrvacic-otkazujem-hrvatski-radijski-festival/2227604/]
The festival gave out several awards, its highest being the Grand Prix. Other awards are The First Award of the [[Radio]] Listeners, The First Award of the Music Editors, The ''[[24sata (Croatia)|24 sata]]'' Readers Award (The ''24 sata'' is a daily [[newspaper]]), then Award Based on the Number of Received Calls by [[Telephone]] and, finally, The Award Based on the Number of [[Internet]] votes.
In 2009 there was one another award. Award [[Toše Proeski]] for the best vocal interpretation. [[Nina Badrić]] won this Award.
== Festival winners ==
*1997 - [[Nina Badrić]] with "Budi tu" *1998 - [[Sandi Cenov]] with "Sunce moje to si ti" *1999 - [[Alen Nižetić]] with "Noćas se rastaju prijatelji" *2000 - [[Ivana Banfić]] feat. [[Dino Merlin]] with "Godinama" *2001 - [[Colonia (music group)|Colonia]] with "Za tvoje snene oči" *2002 - [[Colonia (music group)|Colonia]] with "Oduzimaš mi dah" *2003 - [[Colonia (music group)|Colonia]] with "C'est la vie" *2004 - [[Ivana Banfić]] with "Otisak prsta" *2005 - [[Miroslav Škoro]] with "Svetinja" *2006 - [[Tony Cetinski]] with "Sve je s tobom napokon na mjestu" (in pop-rock category) and [[Marko Perković]] with "Tamo gdje su moji korijeni" (in "zabavna" category) *2007 - [[Toše Proeski]] with "Veži me za sebe" (in pop-rock category) and [[Dražen Zečić]] with "Stani srce" (in "zabavna" category) *2008 - [[Nina Badrić]] feat. [[Ljiljana Petrović Buttler]] with "Kralj života mog" (in pop-rock category), and [[Baruni]] with "Svanut će jutro puno ljubavi" (in "zabavna" category) *2009 - [[Nina Badrić]] & [[Hari Mata Hari]] with "Ne mogu ti reći šta je tuga" (in pop-rock category), and [[Miroslav Škoro]] with "Domovina" (in "zabavna" category)

{{For|the film|Crooner (film)}} {{Redirect|Croon|the rower|Bernardus Croon}} [[Image:Frank Sinatra ca. 1947.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Frank Sinatra]], 1947]]
'''Crooner''' is an American epithet given primarily to male singers of [[jazz standards]], mostly from the [[Great American Songbook]], backed by either a full [[orchestra]], a [[big band]] or a piano. Originally it was an ironic term denoting a sentimental singing style made possible by the use of microphones. Some performers, such as [[Russ Columbo]], did not accept the term:<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=p_wjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yiEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5345,2605998&dq=russ+columbo&hl=en |title=Russ Columbo Doesn't Croon |date=1 November 1931 |work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|Milwaukee Journal]] |accessdate=24 June 2010}}</ref> [[Frank Sinatra]] once said that he did not consider himself or [[Bing Crosby]] "crooners".<ref>CBS Special [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LesuXaSkDDc "Sinatra The Legend"] recording of It Was A Very Good Year (1965)</ref>
==History== [[Image:Perry Como, New York, ca. Oct. 1946 (William P. Gottlieb 01641).jpg|thumb|left|180px|[[Perry Como]], October 1946]] [[Image:Gene Austin 01.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Gene Austin]]]] {{listen | filename = Learn_To_Croon_sung_by_Bing_Crosby.ogg | title = "Learn to Croon" | description = [[Bing Crosby]] demonstrates how to croon in this 1933 recording | format = [[Ogg]] }} This dominant popular vocal style coincided with the advent of radio broadcasting and [[electrical recording]]. Before the advent of the [[microphone]], popular singers like [[Al Jolson]] had to project to the rear seats of a theater, as did opera singers, which made for a very loud vocal style. The microphone made possible the more personal style.<ref name="Crooners">{{cite web |url=http://www.shsu.edu/~lis_fwh/book/roots_of_rock/support/crooner/EarlyCroonersIntro2.htm |title=The Coming of the Crooners |author=Whitcomb, Ian |work=Survey of American Popular Music |publisher=Sam Houston State University |accessdate=24 June 2010}}</ref> [[Al Bowlly]], [[Gene Austin]], [[Art Gillham]] and, by some historical accounts, [[Vaughn De Leath]]<ref>''Father of Radio: The Autobiography of Lee de Forest'', 1950, page 351.</ref><ref>Irving Settel, ''A Pictorial History of Radio'', p. 58, Grosset & Dunlap (1967).</ref> are often credited as inventors of the crooning style, but [[Rudy Vallée]] became far more popular,<ref name="Crooners"/> beginning in 1928. He could be heard by anyone with a phonograph or a radio.<ref name="Crooners"/>
:"In his popular radio program, which began with his floating greeting, 'Heigh ho, everybody,' beamed in from a New York City night club, he stood like a statue, surrounded by clean-cut collegiate band musicians and cradling a saxophone in his arms."
His first film, ''[[The Vagabond Lover]]'', was promoted with the line, "Men Hate Him! Women Love Him!"<ref name="Crooners"/> while his success brought press warnings of the "Vallee Peril": this "punk from Maine" with the "dripping voice" required mounted police to beat back screaming, swooning females at his vaudeville shows.<ref>{{cite book |title=The Rise of the Crooners: Gene Austin, Russ Columbo, Bing Crosby, Nick Lucas, Johnny Marvin, and Rudy Vallee |last1= Pitts |first1=Michael |last2= Hoffman |first2= Frank |series= Studies and Documentation in the History of Popular Entertainment, No. 2 |year=2002 |publisher=The Scarecrow Press |location=Lanham, Md. |isbn=0-8108-4081-2 |oclc=46976469 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Deb9AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq=%22Vallee+Peril%22&source=bl&ots=NLiYhqfZBo&sig=jz5xP3qG1-lLpPHTuDJNfkzskjA&hl=en&sa=X&ei=glCHVO_xIcOngwSB34KYDA&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Vallee%20Peril%22&f=false |page=32}}</ref>
By the early 1930s the term "crooner" had taken on a pejorative connotation.<ref name="Crooners"/> Cardinal [[William Henry O'Connell|William O'Connell]] of [[Boston]] and the [[New York Singing Teachers Association]] (NYSTA) both publicly denounced the vocal form, O'Connell calling it "base", "degenerate", "defiling" and un-American and NYSTA adding "corrupt".<ref name="Crooners"/> Even ''[[The New York Times]]'' predicted that crooning would be just a passing fad. The newspaper printed, "They sing like that because they can’t help it. Their style is begging to go out of fashion…. Crooners will soon go the way of tandem bicycles, mah jongg and midget golf."<ref name="Crooners"/> Voice range shifted from [[tenor]] (Vallée) to [[baritone]] ([[Russ Columbo]], [[Bing Crosby]]).<ref name="Crooners"/> Still, a 1931 record by Dick Robinson, "Crosby, Columbo & Vallee", called upon men to fight "these public enemies" brought into homes via radio.<ref name="Crooners"/>
Although the term is rarely used to describe a female singer, Vaughn De Leath, [[Annette Hanshaw]], [[Mildred Bailey]] (at the beginning of her career) and [[Helen Rowland]] have been cited in the category of crooners.
The genre enjoyed popularity within the former [[Soviet Union]] with [[Mark Reizen]], [[Leonid Utyosov]], [[Pavel Lisitsian]], [[Georg Ots]], [[Oleg Anofriyev]], [[Muslim Magomayev (musician)|Muslim Magomayev]], and [[Joseph Kobzon]] leading the way.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} Their performances had a variety of influences including [[ballad (music)|ballads]] and [[swing music|swing]] and was included in popular film soundtracks.{{citation needed|date=September 2010}}
== Decline == After 1954 popular music became dominated by other styles, especially [[rock 'n' roll]], while the music of latter-day crooners such as [[Perry Como]] and [[Matt Monro]] was recategorized by radio stations as [[easy listening]] or [[adult contemporary]]. Crooners have remained popular among fans of traditional pop music, with contemporary performers such as [[Tony Bennett]], [[Barry Manilow]], [[Brian Evans (singer)|Brian Evans]], [[Richard Hawley]], [[Harry Connick Jr.]], [[Michael Bublé]], [[Neil Hannon]], [[Peter Cincotti]], [[Hamilton Leithauser]], [[Matteo Brancaleoni]] and [[Engelbert Humperdinck (singer)|Engelbert Humperdinck]] keeping the form alive. [[Bing Crosby]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Dick Powell]], [[Nat King Cole]], [[Andy Williams]], [[Bobby Darin]] and [[Jimmy Durante]] incorporated other popular styles into their music, such as [[blues]], [[dixieland]] and even native [[Hawaiian music]].{{citation needed|date=October 2009}}
==Country crooners== Due to the country songs popularized by Bing Crosby, the crooning style of singing became an enduring part of [[country music]].<ref>Bing Crosby, "I'm an Old Cowhand," original mono recordings from 1933-1944, ASV Mono, Living Era, 1995.</ref> Bing Crosby achieved a million seller with his 1940 rendition of the song "[[New San Antonio Rose| San Antonio Rose]]", originally recorded by [[Bob Wills & His Texas Playboys]]. In 1942 Perry Como had a smash hit with "[[Deep in the Heart of Texas]]"; Bing Crosby, who had an enormous influence on Perry Como, covered this song and took it to the #3 position in the US chart that same year. [[Eddy Arnold]], [[Jim Reeves]] and [[Ray Price (musician)|Ray Price]] are especially well known for their country crooner standards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1587136/nashville-skyline-remembering-eddy-arnold.jhtml|title=NASHVILLE SKYLINE: Remembering Eddy Arnold|last=Flippo|first=Chet|work=[[Country Music Television]]|date=8 May 2008|accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6205510/a-tribute-to-country-crooner-jim-reeves-on-the-50th-anniversary-of-his-death|title=billboard.com: A Tribute to Country Crooner Jim Reeves on the 50th Anniversary of His Death|last=Dauphin|first=Chuck|date=1 August 2014|accessdate=6 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/entertainment/music/headlines/20131216-influential-country-crooner-ray-price-dies-at-87.ece|title= dallasnews.com: Influential country crooner Ray Price dies at 87|last=Wilonsky|first=Robert|date=16 December 2013|accessdate=6 September 2014}}</ref> [[Dean Martin]] is rather famous for the country music he recorded in the period when he was working for Reprise Records. Fellow Italian-American crooner Perry Como recorded several albums with country producer [[Chet Atkins]] in Nashville. Regular, non-country crooners scored hits with pop versions of country-songs: Tony Bennett had a ''Billboard'' #1 hit in 1951 with his rendition of Hank Williams' "[[Cold, Cold Heart]]", which was also performed by Louis Armstrong; Perry Como had a ''Billboard'' #1 hit in 1953 with his version of "[[Don't Let the Stars Get in Your Eyes]]", a #1 country hit for its author [[Slim Willet]] and a #4 country hit for Ray Price; [[Guy Mitchell]] scored a ''Billboard'' #1 in 1959 with "[[Heartaches by the Number]]", a country-hit for Ray Price; Engelbert Humperdinck achieved a 1967 UK #1 hit with "[[Release Me (1946 song)|Release Me]]", another song already made famous by Ray Price in 1954. In 1970, Ray Price had a #1 U.S. country hit and a #11 ''Billboard'' Hot 100 hit with the song "[[For the Good Times (song)|For the Good Times]]" written by [[Kris Kristofferson]]; subsequently Perry Como's rendition reached #7 in 1973 on the UK Singles Chart.

{{Infobox musician | name = Darci Lynne Farmer | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = <!-- Leave blank per template instructions ("only use if different from name"). --> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|2004|10|12}} | birth_place = [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]], U.S. | residence = | occupation = [[Ventriloquist]], singer | instrument = Vocals | subject = | influences = | notable_work = | years_active = 2014–present | website = {{URL|https://darcilynne.com}} }} '''Darci Lynne Farmer''' (born October 12, 2004<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hall|first1=Richard|title=10 things about 'America's Got Talent' winner Darci Lynne Farmer you didn't know|url=https://newsok.com/article/5564973|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=4 September 2017}}</ref>) is an American [[ventriloquist]]. She was the winner of [[America's Got Talent (season 12)|season twelve]] of the [[NBC]] competition show ''[[America's Got Talent]]''.
Farmer became both the third female and third child to win ''America's Got Talent'', following [[Bianca Ryan]] in [[America's Got Talent (season 1)|season one]] and [[Grace VanderWaal]] in [[America's Got Talent (season 11)|season eleven]]. She was also the third ventriloquist to win, following [[Terry Fator]] in [[America's Got Talent (season 2)|season two]] and [[Paul Zerdin]] in [[America's Got Talent (season 10)|season ten]].
==Early life== Darci Lynne Farmer lives in [[Oklahoma City|Oklahoma City, Oklahoma]]. She was born on October 12, 2004. Growing up, Farmer loved to sing, but she was shy and was afraid to perform in front of an audience.<ref>{{cite web|title=About {{!}} Darci Lynne|url=https://darcilynne.com/about|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170907033721/https://www.darcilynne.com/about/|archive-date=7 September 2017|dead-url=no}}</ref> Her parents encouraged her to overcome her shyness by participating in the ''International Cinderella Scholarship Program'' where she was crowned International Mini Miss. At that pageant she also met International Teen titleholder, Laryssa Bonacquisti, a young ventriloquist who inspired her to try ventriloquism herself.<ref name=ok>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Interview, photos and video: 12-year-old Oklahoma City ventriloquist Darci Lynne Farmer prepares to go back on 'America's Got Talent' |url=http://newsok.com/article/5558909|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=4 August 2017}}</ref> She then asked her parents, Clarke and Misty Farmer, for a puppet, insisting that it would overcome her shyness. On her tenth birthday, her parents presented her with a puppet. Farmer's idol is past ''America's Got Talent'' winner [[Terry Fator]]. Because ventriloquism is not very common, Farmer made a commitment that she personally wanted to keep the art of ventriloquism alive.
In 2014, she entered ''Edmond's Got Talent'' where she won first prize after a month's preparation on Bonacquisti's tips. She was soon brought to the attention of ventriloquy coach Gary Owen, who was so impressed by Farmer's skill that he voluntarily agreed to be her coach and business manager.<ref name=tds>{{cite web|last=Hurst|first=Steve|title=A New Star is Born|work=The Dummy Shoppe|url=http://thedummyshoppe.com/blog/a-new-star-is-born/|date=4 November 2016}}</ref> Since then she has worked with Owen and vocal teacher Tiana Plemons.<ref name=ok/> In 2015, she won first place in both the junior division at ''Oklahoma's Got Talent'' and ''Oklahoma Kids'', and won Broadway, Specialty Acts, and overall Entertainer of the Year at ''American Kids'' in [[Branson, Missouri]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Franklin|first1=Dallas|title=Young Oklahoma girl shows off her ventriloquism skills for KFOR ahead of national debut|url=http://kfor.com/2016/03/25/young-oklahoma-girl-shows-off-her-ventriloquism-skills-for-kfor-ahead-of-national-debut/|work=[[KFOR-TV|KFOR]]|date=25 March 2016}}</ref> In March 2016, Farmer made an appearance on ''[[Little Big Shots]]'', performing "[[I Want to Be a Cowboy's Sweetheart]]" with Katie,<ref name=lbs>{{cite news|last1=Stubblebine|first1=Allison|title=Watch All of Darci Lynne Farmer's 'Little Big Shots' Appearances Before She Won 'AGT'|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/television/7973555/darci-lynne-farmer-little-big-shots-performances-videos-agt-winner|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=21 September 2017}}</ref> and in July 2016, she became the first child ventriloquist ever to perform on an evening show in the 40-year history of the ''[[Vent Haven Museum|Vent Haven]] International Ventriloquists' ConVENTion'', where she fronted for celebrity ventriloquists [[Kevin Johnson (ventriloquist)|Kevin Johnson]] and Todd Oliver.<ref name=tds/> Then, in March 2017, she appeared on the British version of ''[[Little Big Shots (UK TV series)|Little Big Shots]]'', again performing "I Want to Be a Cowboy's Sweetheart" with Katie.<ref name=lbs/>
==Career==
===2017: ''America's Got Talent''=== Farmer competed on the twelfth season of ''America's Got Talent'' in 2017. During the first episode broadcast on May 30, Farmer and her puppet, a girly rabbit named Petunia, performed [[George Gershwin]]'s "[[Summertime (George Gershwin song)|Summertime]]".<ref name="agt">{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Oklahoma ventriloquist Darci Lynne Farmer breaks 'America's Got Talent' records, earns 306 million views on social media|url=https://newsok.com/article/5565102/oklahoma-ventriloquist-darci-lynne-farmer-breaks-americas-got-talent-records-earns-306-million-views-on-social-media|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=21 September 2017}}</ref> The comedy–singing act featured Petunia cutting off Farmer so Petunia could continue singing instead. Judge [[Mel B]] praised the act and pressed her Golden Buzzer, allowing Farmer to bypass the [[America's Got Talent#Judge Cuts|judge cuts]] and go straight to the quarterfinals. The video of this performance became the most socially viewed video in the show's history within 30 hours of broadcast,<ref name="agt" /> and was later named {{abbr|No.|Number}} 4 on [[YouTube]]'s list of the top 10 trending videos of 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last=Allocca|first=Kevin|url=https://youtube.googleblog.com/2017/12/its-time-for-youtuberewind-celebrating.html|title=It's time for #YouTubeRewind: Celebrating what you watched, shared, and created in 2017|work=Official YouTube Blog|date=6 December 2017|accessdate=8 October 2018}}</ref>
For Farmer's first live presentation after her Golden Buzzer performance, she serenaded [[Mel B]] with her shy, stuttering [[Motown]] mouse puppet, Oscar, performing [[Smokey Robinson]]'s "[[Who's Lovin' You]]".<ref name="agt" /> Judges [[Howie Mandel]], Mel B, [[Heidi Klum]], and [[Simon Cowell]] gave Farmer standing ovations. For this performance, Farmer received enough viewer votes to move on to the semifinals, where she brought her puppet Edna Doorknocker to sing [[Aretha Franklin]]'s "[[(You Make Me Feel Like) A Natural Woman]]",<ref name="agt" /> and stood next to the judges' table so Edna could flirt with Simon Cowell. Again, all four judges gave Farmer a standing ovation. Viewers voted Farmer through to the finals.
For her final competition appearance, Farmer performed [[The Beatles]]' "[[With a Little Help from My Friends]]",<ref name="agt" /> with Petunia and Oscar interacting for comedic effect. Again, she earned standing ovations and judges' praise; Cowell predicted, "I think you're going to win."<ref>{{cite news|last=Seemayer|first=Zach|url=http://www.etonline.com/exclusive-darci-lynne-farmer-overcome-joy-after-americas-got-talent-win-talks-prize-money-plans|title=EXCLUSIVE: Darci Lynne Farmer 'Overcome With Joy' After 'America's Got Talent' Win, Talks Prize Money Plans|work=[[Entertainment Tonight]]|date=20 September 2017}}</ref> For the finale in episode 22, Farmer fulfilled her dream by performing "[[Anything You Can Do (song)|Anything You Can Do]]" from ''[[Annie Get Your Gun (musical)|Annie Get Your Gun]]'' with her idol and mentor [[Terry Fator]], with Farmer singing as Petunia and Fator singing as Winston the Impersonating Turtle. After tripping over the first line of the song, she recovered and the act continued.<ref>{{cite news|last=Maglio|first=Tony|url=https://www.thewrap.com/darci-lynne-farmer-petunia-terry-fator-video/|title=Watch 'America's Got Talent' Puppet Duel With Darci Lynne, Season 2 Winner Terry Fator (Video)|work=[[TheWrap]]|date=21 September 2017}}</ref> The field was cut to the top five, and then to the top two finalists, Farmer and [[Angelica Hale]]. Host [[Tyra Banks]] then announced Farmer was the winner of the season, having received the most votes out of the 52 million votes<ref name="agt" /> cast. With the win, Farmer received the $1 million prize and a headline gig at [[Planet Hollywood Las Vegas|Planet Hollywood]] in Las Vegas, originally set for November 3 and 4 but two additional shows were added on November 2 and 5 after the first two dates sold out. The Las Vegas shows also featured [[Angelica Hale]], [[Preacher Lawson]] and [[Light Balance]].
====Post-''America's Got Talent''==== Farmer was a guest on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'' in September.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Video: 'America's Got Talent' winner Darci Lynne Farmer performs on 'The Ellen DeGeneres Show,' returns home to Oklahoma|url=https://newsok.com/article/5565548|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=25 September 2017}}</ref> She appeared in [[Jeff Dunham|Jeff Dunham's]] October video, ''The Haunted House on Dunham Hill'', in which she takes three of her puppets [[trick-or-treating]] at Dunham's home, where they encounter him and some of his puppets.<ref name="NewsOK">{{cite web|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Watch: 'America's Got Talent' winner Darci Lynne Farmer trick-or-treats at Jeff Dunham's house in fun Halloween video|url=http://newsok.com/watch-americas-got-talent-winner-darci-lynne-farmer-trick-or-treats-at-jeff-dunhams-house-in-fun-halloween-video/article/5569585|website=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|accessdate=20 November 2017|date=26 October 2017}}</ref> In November, she made a guest appearance during a [[Terry Fator]] performance at the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Tulsa, [[Catoosa, Oklahoma]].<ref>{{Cite tweet |author=Hard Rock Tulsa|author-link=Hard Rock Cafe#Casinos and hotels|user=TulsaHardRock|number=930103069421039616|date = 13 November 2017 |title=Thank you to everyone who came out to The Joint last night to see @terryfator and a special performance from @ItsDarciLynne!}}</ref> In November, she appeared in ''A Very [[Pentatonix]] Christmas'' performing "O Easter Egg" (an [[Easter]]-themed parody of "[[O Christmas Tree]]") with Petunia.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lorge|first1=Melinda|title=An "America's Got Talent" champ brings humor to the Pentatonix Christmas special|url=https://rarecountry.com/performances/an-americas-got-talent-champ-brings-humor-to-the-pentatonix-christmas-special/|work=Rare Country|date=28 November 2017}}</ref>
In December, Farmer appeared as part of the charity event ''One Night With the Stars'' at [[Madison Square Garden]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Viagas|first1=Robert|title=Constantine Maroulis, Fran Drescher, and Darci Lynne Added to ''One Night With the Stars''|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/constantine-maroulis-fran-drescher-and-darci-lynne-added-to-one-night-with-the-stars|work=[[Playbill]]|date=29 November 2017}}</ref> Her December 16 homecoming show ''[[iHeartMedia]] and [[KJYO|KJ103]] Present Darci Lynne'' sold out within six minutes of the tickets going on sale. As a result, a matinee show earlier the same day and then later another two shows on December 17 were added.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title='America's Got Talent' winner Darci Lynne Farmer adds fourth Oklahoma City homecoming show|url=http://newsok.com/article/5574711|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=5 December 2017}}</ref> On December 31, she performed at [[Caesars Palace]] in [[Las Vegas]] along with [[Fergie (singer)|Fergie]] as part of a New Year's Eve event.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morris|first1=David|title=Caesars Palace Ushers in 2018 with Major Star Power and Preps for Two Openings|url=http://vegasseven.com/2018/01/01/caesars-palace-ushers-in-2018-with-major-star-power-and-preps-for-two-openings|work=Vegas Seven|date=1 January 2018}}</ref>
===2018–present: ''Darci Lynne and Friends Live''=== In November 2017, ''Darci Lynne and Friends Live'', a national tour, was announced, starting with five locations, to take place in January and February 2018,<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title='America's Got Talent' winner Darci Lynne Farmer announces first theater tour|url=http://newsok.com/americas-got-talent-winner-darci-lynne-farmer-announces-first-theater-tour/article/5573964|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=28 November 2017}}</ref> which was later expanded to 46 locations taking place between January 2018 and January 2019,<ref>{{cite web|title=Darci Lynne - Events|url=https://www.facebook.com/pg/ItsDarciLynne/events/}}</ref> including 9 Christmas performances in November and December, referred to as ''Rocking Around the Christmas Tree with Darci Lynne and Friends''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Season 12 winner Darci Lynne Farmer returns to 'America's Got Talent' tonight, Oklahoma illusionist Rob Lake reveals when he will next perform on the show|url=https://newsok.com/article/5604808|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=15 August 2018}}</ref>
In January 2018, Farmer appeared on [[Today (U.S. TV program)|''Today'']] with Oscar, performing "Who's Lovin' You".<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Watch: 'America's Got Talent' winner Darci Lynne Farmer reprises soulful classic on 'Today' show|url=https://newsok.com/article/5579617/watch-americas-got-talent-winner-darci-lynne-farmer-reprises-soulful-classic-on-today-show|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=15 January 2018}}</ref> In March, she appeared on the ''[[Grand Ole Opry]]''<ref>{{Cite tweet |author-link=Grand Ole Opry|user=opry|number=972301159271723009|date = 9 March 2018 |title=This girl's got TALENT! So proud to have @ItsDarciLynne make her #OpryDebut tonight along with Katie! 👏🏻👏🏻👏🏻 #Opry}}</ref> and made a cameo appearance on the ''[[2018 Kids' Choice Awards|Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards]]'',<ref>{{cite news|last1=Haring|first1=Bruce|title=Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards 2018 Winners – The Complete List|url=http://deadline.com/2018/03/nickelodeon-kids-choice-awards-2018-winners-the-complete-list-1202352942/|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=24 March 2018}}</ref> and then returned to ''[[Little Big Shots]]'' in April as "a Little Big Shots legend", where she performed "[[Shout (The Isley Brothers song)|Shout]]" by [[the Isley Brothers]] with Oscar.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Tramel|first1=Jimmie|title=Darci Lynne Farmer returning to series where she made national TV debut (copy)|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/darci-lynne-farmer-returning-to-series-where-she-made-national/article_3762abe4-5851-5cbe-8cdf-98fa8f537bcd.html|work=[[Tulsa World]]|date=8 April 2018}}</ref> In July, she participated in the 2018 [[Starkey Hearing Technologies|Starkey Hearing Foundation]] gala.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Belcamino|first1=Kristi|title=Bill Clinton, Alice Cooper, Sinbad, more walk the red carpet at St. Paul's Starkey Gala|url=https://www.twincities.com/2018/07/15/bill-clinton-makes-guest-appearance-at-starkey-gala-in-st-paul/|work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=15 July 2018}}</ref> In August, she returned to ''AGT'' as a guest performer, singing "Show Off" from ''[[The Drowsy Chaperone]]'' with Petunia.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lockhart|first1=Tiffany C.|title=America's Got Talent: First Results Are In. Season 12 Winner Performs.|url=https://www.tvovermind.com/americas-got-talent/americas-got-talent-first-results-season-12-winner-performs|work=[[Screener (website)|TVOvermind]]|date=16 August 2018}}</ref> In September, she appeared as a guest in an episode of ''[[Kids Baking Championship]]''.<ref name=agttc/> In November, she was a guest on ''[[Steve (talk show)|Steve]]'', where she performed "[[Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (song)|Rudolf the Red-Nosed Reindeer]]" with Petunia,<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Video: Darci Lynne Farmer performs Christmas classic on Steve Harvey's new show, details revealed of her holiday TV special|url=https://newsok.com/article/5616238/video-darci-lynne-farmer-performs-christmas-classic-on-steve-harveys-new-show-details-revealed-of-her-holiday-tv-special|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=27 November 2018}}</ref> and later sang "[[Jingle Bell Rock]]" with Petunia during [[NBC]]'s ''[[Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree|Christmas in Rockefeller Center]]'' telecast.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Haas|first1=Susan|title=Rockefeller Center tree lighting: Diana Ross, Tony Bennett and other things you missed|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2018/11/29/rockefeller-center-tree-lighting-diana-ross-and-things-you-missed/2145057002/|work=[[USA Today]]|date=29 November 2018}}</ref> In December, she will return to the ''Grand Ole Opry''.<ref>{{cite web|title=December 4, 2018 {{!}} Opry at the Ryman|url=https://www.opry.com/calendar/opry-ryman-tue-4-dec|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181130115814/https://www.opry.com/calendar/opry-ryman-tue-4-dec|archive-date=30 November 2018|dead-url=no}}</ref>
Also in December, Farmer is set to star in her own holiday special, ''Darci Lynne: My Hometown Christmas'', which will feature guest appearances by [[Pentatonix]], [[Hunter Hayes]], [[Lindsey Stirling]], [[Toby Keith]], [[Kristin Chenoweth]], the four ''America's Got Talent'' judges, Simon Cowell, Howie Mandel, Heidi Klum and Mel B, and Lonnie Chavis from ''[[This Is Us (TV series)|This Is Us]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=AMERICA'S GOT TALENT Winner Darci Lynne Farmer Celebrates the Holidays with TV Special|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/article/AMERICAS-GOT-TALENT-Winner-Darci-Lynne-Farmer-Celebrates-the-Holidays-with-TV-Special-20181126|work=[[BroadwayWorld]]|date=26 November 2018}}</ref>
In January 2019, Farmer will appear in ''[[America's Got Talent: The Champions]]''.<ref name=agttc>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title=Darci Lynne Farmer to appear on new 'America's Got Talent: The Champions'|url=https://newsok.com/article/5612206/darci-lynne-farmer-to-appear-on-new-americas-got-talent-the-champions|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=18 October 2018}}</ref>
In October 2018, Farmer announced a second tour starting in February 2019, ''Darci Lynne and Friends: Fresh Out of the Box''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McDonnell|first1=Brandy|title='America's Got Talent' winner Darci Lynne Farmer planning OKC hometown show on 2019 tour|url=https://newsok.com/article/5612715/americas-got-talent-winner-darci-lynne-farmer-planning-okc-hometown-show-on-2019-tour|work=[[The Oklahoman|NewsOK]]|date=24 October 2018}}</ref>
==Reputation and accolades==
Farmer's success on ''America's Got Talent'' has been credited with helping to bring ventriloquism back to the general public's attention.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Purcell|first1=John|title=Playful puppets promote bullying prevention at Tecler|url=https://www.recordernews.com/news/local-news/103651|work=The Recorder|date=30 October 2017|quote=Sharpwolf said many children have become excited about ventriloquism following the latest season of "America's Got Talent!" where a 12-year-old singing ventriloquist, Darci Lynne Farmer, was voted the champion.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Stone|first1=Ken|title=Darci Lynne 'AGT' win wildy cheered by veteran ventriloquists: 'Bring us on tour'|url=https://mynewsla.com/hollywood/2017/09/22/darci-lynne-agt-win-wildy-cheered-by-veteran-ventriloquists-bring-us-on-tour/|work=MyNewsLA.com|date=22 September 2017}}</ref>
Bill King of ''[[BuddyTV]]'' described Farmer's final ''America's Got Talent'' performance as "so seamless you need to be reminded of its difficulty".<ref>{{cite news|last1=King|first1=Bill|title='America's Got Talent' Season 12: Top 10 Performance Rankings|url=http://www.buddytv.com/slideshows/americas-got-talent/americas-got-talent-season-12-top-10-performance-rankings-83222.aspx|work=[[BuddyTV]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118181432/http://www.buddytv.com/slideshows/americas-got-talent/americas-got-talent-season-12-top-10-performance-rankings-83222.aspx|archive-date=18 January 2018|date=20 September 2017|dead-url=yes}}</ref> Talking to ''[[USA Today]]'', [[Terry Fator]] said of Farmer that "she is, at 12 years old, one of the most unbelievable, perfect ventriloquists I've ever seen, and she'll only get better",<ref>{{cite news|last1=Mallenbaum|first1=Carly|title='America's Got Talent' winner Darci Lynne explains all the onstage crying and laughing|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2017/09/21/americas-got-talent-winner-darci-lynne-farmer/687974001/|work=[[USA Today]]|date=21 September 2017}}</ref> and later called her "one of the most talented human beings on the planet" in an interview with ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cheng|first1=Andrea|title=Terry Fator on Darci Lynne Farmer's 'America's Got Talent' Win: 'I Felt Like a Proud Dad'|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/lifestyle/7974035/terry-fator-on-darci-lynne-farmer-americas-got-talent-win|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=25 September 2017}}</ref> Professional ventriloquist Sammy King said in an interview with ''[[Fountain Hills Times|The Fountain Hills Times]]'' that "she is very gifted, a great singer and has tremendous comedic timing",<ref>{{cite news|last1=Charzuk|first1=Barb|title=The 'King' of ventriloquism|url=http://www.fhtimes.com/features/featured_stories/the-king-of-ventriloquism/article_9afb078e-d47a-11e7-ab36-4f9c35333f0c.html|work=[[Fountain Hills Times|The Fountain Hills Times]]|date=29 November 2017}}</ref> while [[Jay Johnson (ventriloquist)|Jay Johnson]] described her on his personal blog as "a wonderfully talented girl" with "near perfect" ventriloquism technique and "singing chops [that] could stand alone without the puppet assistance", whose "dedication to the art and ... young spirit will influence a generation of belly talkers to come".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://hellandhayes.blogspot.co.uk/2017/09/congratulations-darci-lynne-farmer.html |title=Congratulations Darci Lynne Farmer - Winner |last=Johnson |first=Jay |date=21 September 2017}}</ref>
==Characters== * Petunia – A singing white rabbit "who thinks she's a diva". * Oscar – A stuttering and nervous [[Motown]] mouse who has a crush on [[Mel B]]. * Edna Doorknocker – A naughty old lady with a crush on [[Simon Cowell]]. * Katie – A sassy cowgirl who [[Yodeling|yodels]]. * Okie – A yellow duck who sometimes impersonates [[Elvis Presley]]. * Scarlett – A sassy debutante fox. * Ace – A big brown monkey.<ref name=interview>{{cite web|title=Darci Farmer appears on NBC's "Little Big Shots"|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q87-N5itS_E&t=342|website=YouTube}}</ref> * Nigel – A very smart British bird.<ref name=interview/>
==Personal life== Farmer attends Deer Creek Middle School near her home in [[Edmond, Oklahoma]]. She missed the first day of her seventh grade year due to appearing live on ''America's Got Talent'' on August 16.<ref name=ok/>
Her parents are Clarke and Misty Farmer. Farmer has three brothers: Nick, Dalton, and Nate.<ref>{{Cite news|last1=Srivatsa|first1=Amrutha|url=https://www.earnthenecklace.com/americas-got-talent-2017-winner-darci-lynne-family-parents-facts/|title="America's Got Talent" 2017 Winner, Darci Lynne's Family: 5 Facts about Darci Lynne's Parents|date=21 September 2017|work=Earn The Necklace|access-date=21 September 2017}}</ref>

Guillaume Gouraud (General Manager and Artistic Director) | industry = [[Video game industry|Computer and video games]] | products = [[Video game]]s | revenue = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | homepage = [http://www.darkworks.com/ www.darkworks.com] }} '''Darkworks S.A.''' was an independent [[video game developer]] and technology company based in [[Paris]], [[France]]. The company is known for its games that include ''[[Alone in the Dark: The New Nightmare]]'' and ''[[Cold Fear]]''. Darkworks was founded in 1998 by Antoine Villette (President) and Guillaume Gouraud (General Manager and Artistic Director). The studio employed more than 100 people. In October 2011, the studio was placed into [[Liquidation#Compulsory liquidation|Compulsory liquidation]] and was closed.{{cite web | url=http://www.gamekult.com/actu/darkworks-et-nobilis-en-redressement-judiciaire-A0000096391.html | title=Darkworks et Nobilis en redressement judiciaire | date=2011-09-19 | publisher=gamekult.com | accessdate=2012-02-26}}{{cite web | url=http://www.factornews.com/news-33413-Darkworks_Game_over.html | title=Darkworks : Game over | date=2011-10-30 | publisher=factornews.com | accessdate=2012-02-26}} ==PlayAll== In addition to its game development activities, the company lead several other companies on PlayAll, an integrated multimedia production toolchain and set of engines funded by the [[Cap Digital]] cluster. ==TriOviz for Games Technology== {{main|TriOviz for Games}} [[Anaglyph 3D#Inficolor 3D|TriOviz]] company in partnership with Darkworks developed the TriOviz for Games Technology, a technological solution that enables smooth stereoscopic 3D conversion of video games or multimedia products. Following Darkworks [[Liquidation]], TriOviz bought the companies stereoscopic activities and teams.{{cite web | url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/39308/TriOviz_Buys_Darkworkss_Stereoscopic_Middleware_Activities.php | title=TriOviz Buys Darkworks's Stereoscopic Middleware Activities | date=2011-12-22 | publisher=[[Gamasutra]] | accessdate=2012-02-26}} ==Games== {|class="wikitable" |- ! {{infobox stadium | name = Davit Abashidze Stadium
დავით აბაშიძის სტადიონი | nickname = Zestafoni Stadium | image = File:Davit Abashidze Stadium.jpg | fullname = | former_names = | location = {{flagicon|Georgia}} [[Zestafoni]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[FC Zestafoni]] | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = Yes | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 4,558 | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = {{convert|105|x|70|m|abbr=on}} | acreage = | tenants = [[FC Zestafoni]] }} '''David Abashidze Stadium''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Zestafoni]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. It is used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[FC Zestafoni]]. The stadium is able to hold 4,100 people and opened in 1952. Zestafoni '''David Abashidze Stadium''' (former Central Stadium) was built by the Zestafoni Ferro-alloy Plant. A couple of matches were held on the stadium before its opening in 1951. In 1952-1989 and 1999-2003 of Georgian Championship team [[FC Metallurg Zestafoni]] held matches on the Zestafoni central stadium, in 1990-1998 it was a home stadium for [[FC Margveti Zestafoni]]. Since 2004, FC Zestafoni has held home matches in the stadium. In 1981, reconstruction work was done on the arena; the west stand was roofed and the east stand was constructed. After these works capacity of the stadium increased to 8000 seats. In 2004, after establishing [[FC Zestafoni]], central stadium was repaired and is still being repaired to renew the arena and comply with international standards. In 2005, works were done to renew the grass surface on the stadium. Georgian workers have constructed new drainage system of German technology. The field is watered with a watering system fromf an American Company “Rainbird”. (This watering system was successfully used on eight stadiums during the 2004 European Championship in Portugal.) On the Zestafoni central stadium, the field surface, “Natural Green Carpet”, is made by the Ukrainian firm “Lidia-Park”. [[FC Zestafoni]] management plans to build a new base for the club. Lots of new football fields have been constructed in Zestafoni (among them one with an artificial surface). Relevant infrastructure is being made – work out rooms are being repaired, building of new tribunes with personal seats is planned, along with the installment of a modern score-board. On 9 April 2010 the Stadium was named after David Abashidze who contributed tremendously to the development and revival of football in Zestafoni. Capacity of the stadium has been increased to 4 558 individual seats. == See also == * [[List of football stadiums in Georgia (country)|Stadiums in Georgia]] {{Coord|42.1112131|43.0256796|display=title|type:landmark}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1952]] [[Category:Sports venues built in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Sports venues in Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Football venues in Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Imereti]]
