Company Profile | publisher=InsideView | accessdate=July 17, 2013}}</ref> | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = Dissolved | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1999 <ref name="insideview-copro" /> | founder = | defunct = {{End date|2012|03|01}} | location_city = [[San Francisco, California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | locations = <!-- Number of locations, stores, offices &c. --> | area_served = [[United States]] | key_people = John Taylor :[[President (corporate title)|President]] and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Samuel "Mouli" Cohen]] :Co-founder | products = SmartSolution, SmartMall, SmartTransit, SmartConcierge, & Jukebox | production = | services = Place-based [[interactive media]] | revenue = {{US$|7,000,000}} <ref name="insideview-copro" /> | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 81 <ref name="insideview-copro" /> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|www.ecastinc.com}} | footnotes = | intl = | bodystyle = }} '''Ecast, Inc.''' was a privately held, venture capital–backed place-based interactive media company that offered advertising, digital music, games, entertainment, and information to bars and nightclubs in the United States.<ref name="privco" /> The company was founded in 1999 and was headquartered in San Francisco, California.<ref name="businessweek-coinfo">{{cite web | url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=27867 | title=Ecast Inc. - Private Company Information | publisher=Bloomberg | work=Businessweek | accessdate=July 17, 2013}}</ref> Ecast, Inc. ceased operations when it closed its Jukebox network on March 1, 2012.<ref name="vt312">{{cite journal | url=http://www.vendingtimes.com/ME2/dirmod.asp?nm=Vending+Features&type=Publishing&mod=Publications%3A%3AArticle&tier=4&id=1FA76E9E03FA4C048872B380ABC0310E | title=Ecast Shuts Down Jukebox Network On March 1 | author=Montano, Nick | journal=Vending Times |date=March 2012 | volume=52 | issue=3}}</ref>
==Services== Its hospitality network delivered digital music, way finding, coupons, social media, third party content, and advertising options to more than 10,000 venues at its peak,<ref name="vt312" /><ref name="domedia">{{cite web | url=http://www.domedia.com/marketplace/companies/companyDetails.jsp?companyid=12952 | title=Ecast, Inc. San Francisco California | publisher=DOmedia | accessdate=July 17, 2013}}</ref> including [[bar (establishment)|bars]], [[nightclub]]s, [[tavern]]s, [[resort]]s, [[hotel]]s, [[restaurant]]s, [[retail|retail stores]], event pavilions, and [[arena]]s.<ref name="businessweek-coinfo" />
===SmartSolution=== [[Touchscreen]] software that served advertising and social media impressions, as well as [[direct marketing associations]] operating on 3rd party hardware platforms.<ref name="businessweek-coinfo" />
===SmartMall=== An [[interactive media]] service that provided shopping customers with up-to-date information on the latest style and trends with editorialized content and coupons/offers.<ref name="businessweek-coinfo" />
===SmartTransit=== An advertising and content service that connected users to advertisers.<ref name="businessweek-coinfo" />
===SmartConcierge=== System that displays interactive images/movies showcasing the amenities of a client’s hotel/resort.<ref name="businessweek-coinfo" />
===Jukebox=== An interactive place-based broadband enabled interactive media service for the bar and nightclub market.<ref name="businessweek-coinfo" /><ref name="vt312" />
==History== The company was founded in 1999 and was headquartered in San Francisco, California.<ref name="businessweek-coinfo" /><ref name="vt312" />
Ecast merged with [[RioPort]] in October 2002.<ref name="RioPort Ecast Merger">{{cite web |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2002/10/14/daily39.html |title=RioPort agrees to merge with Ecast, Inc.}}</ref> Rioport was a digital music download service precursor to [[iTunes]] and was the first service to sign digital download agreements with all 5 of the major music labels.
Ecast, Inc. ceased operations when it closed its Jukebox network on March 1, 2012. The company's board of directors voted for an immediate shutdown after the company failed to raise enough capital to continue operating. Ecast's phones and email were turned off shortly after. AMI Entertainment Network Inc. and TouchTunes Interactive Networks indicated they would accommodate customers no longer able to access the company's services.<ref name="vt312" />
==Controversies==
===TouchTunes patent dispute=== In late 2001, Ecast filed a lawsuit against TouchTunes Music Corporation claiming the company resorted to unfair trade practices by notifying Ecast and its customers that they were infringing TouchTunes' patent.<ref name="law360404">{{cite news | url=http://www.law360.com/articles/1382/touchtunes-and-ecast-settle-patent-disputes | title=TouchTunes and Ecast Settle Patent Disputes | work=Law360 | date=April 29, 2004 | accessdate=July 17, 2013 | author=Meland, Marius | location=New York}}</ref>
On October 15, 2003, Ecast voluntarily dismissed its own claims against TouchTunes for interference with contracts and unfair competition. In January 2004, TouchTunes filed a counterclaim that Ecast infringed on their patent rights by incorporating Touchtunes’ technology into their systems.<ref name="law360404" /><ref name="ttcounterpr">{{cite press release | url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/touchtunes-counterclaims-against-ecast-and-rock-ola-for-patent-infringement-58950327.html | title=TouchTunes Counterclaims Against Ecast and Rock-Ola for Patent Infringement | publisher=PRNewswire-FirstCall | date=January 13, 2004 | accessdate=July 17, 2013}}</ref>
Ecast also had a separate patent infringement case against TouchTunes, charging the company with infringement by selling its jukeboxes within the U.S.<ref name="law360404" />
Ultimately TouchTunes and Ecast agreed to cross-license TouchTunes' U.S. Patent No. 6,308,204 and Ecast's U.S. Patent No. 5,341,350, which it licensed from NSM Music Group Limited.<ref name="law360404" />
===Civil antitrust action=== In September 2005, the Attorney General of the United States filed a civil antitrust action against Ecast, Inc. and NSM Music Group, Ltd. The lawsuit alleged that a February 2003 agreement between the companies agreement was in violation of Section 1 of the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]]. Specifically that the negotiations which eventually led to NSM Music Group manufacturing Ecast's hardware, after their previous manufacturer terminated the supply agreement, included an agreement by NSM to abandon its plans to enter the U.S. market in return for an upfront payment by Ecast. The Attorney General contended that NSM's agreement caused them to abandon their plan to incorporate their own distinctive digital jukebox platform into their physical jukeboxes and enter the United States market.<ref name="usvec905">{{cite court |litigants=U.S. v. Ecast, Inc. and NSM Music Group, Ltd.|vol=|reporter= |opinion=|pinpoint=|court= D.D.C. |date=September 2, 2005 |url=http://www.justice.gov/atr/cases/f210900/210960.htm}}</ref>
The Department of Justice simultaneously announced alongside the lawsuit that it had reached a settlement with NSM and Ecast under which the two companies terminated their non-compete agreement.<ref name="tlj1209">{{cite web | url=http://www.techlawjournal.com/alert/2005/09/08.asp | title=TLJ Daily E-Mail Alert No. 1,209 | publisher=Tech Law Journal | date=September 8, 2005 | accessdate=July 17, 2013}}</ref>
===Samuel "Mouli" Cohen=== {{see also|Samuel "Mouli" Cohen}} In 2009, Ecast co-founder and one-time [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] and Executive Chairman, [[Samuel "Mouli" Cohen]] defrauded 55 investors, including actor [[Danny Glover]] and the [[Vanguard Public Foundation]], of more than $28 million and two lawsuits were filed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lawsuit says ex-Marin executive defrauded investors|url=http://www.contracostatimes.com/ci_12756377|accessdate=17 January 2012}}</ref> Cohen told investors that Ecast, Inc. was about to be acquired by [[Microsoft]]. Based on those false representations, victims purchased some of Cohen’s founders’ shares in Ecast.<ref name="huffpo512">{{cite news | url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/01/samuel-mouli-cohen-sentence-prison_n_1467105.html | title=Samuel 'Mouli' Cohen Sentenced To 22 Years In Prison For $30 Million Fraud | work=Huffington Post | date=May 1, 2012 | agency=Associated Press | accessdate=July 17, 2013 | author=Elias, Paul}}</ref>
A federal grand jury in 2010 indicted Cohen on 32 felony counts of [[fraud]] and [[money laundering]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Fraud suspect indicted; Vanguard among victims|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2010-08-10/business/22212372_1_vanguard-investors-ecast-million-investment-fraud|accessdate=17 January 2012 | work=The San Francisco Chronicle|first=Bob|last=Egelko|date=August 10, 2010}}</ref> and was arrested in August 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ecast Founder Mouli Cohen Convicted Of $30M Fraud|url=http://www.vendingtimes.com/ME2/dirmod.asp?sid=EB79A487112B48A296B38C81345C8C7F&nm=Vending+Features&type=Publishing&mod=Publications%3A%3AArticle&mid=8F3A7027421841978F18BE895F87F791&tier=4&id=79A39282BD784FA398A801919F085EA3|publisher=Vending Times|accessdate=17 January 2012}}</ref> In November 2011, Cohen was found guilty of 15 counts of [[wire fraud]], 11 counts of money laundering, and three counts of [[tax evasion]]. He was acquitted of six additional charges.<ref name="justicegov">{{cite web | url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/can/news/2011/2011_11_10_cohen.convicted.press.pdf | title=Founder And Former Ceo Of Technology Company Convicted Of Defrauding Victims Out Of More Than $30 Million | publisher=Press Release - United States Attorney's Office, Northern District of California | accessdate=October 20, 2013}}</ref> At the courthouse, he was taken into custody.<ref name=justicegov /><ref name="diligen">{{cite web | url=http://www.diligentiagroup.com/due-diligence/red-flags-you-should-seen-a-look-back-at-mouli-cohen/ | title="Red Flags" You Should Have Seen – A Look Back at Mouli Cohen | work=Diligentia Group Inc. | accessdate=17 January 2012 | author=Willingham, Brian}}</ref><ref name="sfc2">{{cite news | url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2011-11-11/bay-area/30389986_1_million-investment-fraud-ecast-fraud-charges | title=Mouli Cohen guilty in $30 million investment fraud | work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date=11 November 2011 | accessdate=17 January 2012 | first=Bob | last=Egelko}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Samuel "Mouli" Cohen]]
