==Analysis== [[Chris Taylor (journalist)|Chris Taylor]] called the Force "largely a mystery" in ''Star Wars''.<ref name="taylor-58" /> Taylor ascribes the "more poetic, more spiritual ... and more demonstrative" descriptions of the Force in ''The Empire Strikes Back'' to [[Lawrence Kasdan]], who co-wrote the film, but says the film does little to expand audiences' understanding of it.<ref name="taylor-58" /> In 1997, Lucas said that the more detail he articulated about the Force and how it works, the more it took away from its core meaning.<ref name="bouzereau-35">[[#bouzereau|Bouzereau]], p. 35</ref> ''[[Kotaku]]'' suggests Johnson depicted more nuance in the Force in ''The Last Jedi'' than Lucas did in his films.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kotaku.com/star-wars-the-last-jedi-has-a-really-cool-take-on-the-1821336396|title=Star Wars: The Last Jedi Has A Really Cool Take On The Force|last=Hamilton|first=Kirk|date=December 15, 2017|work=[[Kotaku]]|access-date=December 27, 2017|publisher=[[Univision Communications]]|language=en-US}}</ref> According to Rob Weinert-Kendt, the "Force theme" in [[John Williams]]' score represents the power and responsibility of wielding the Force.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uwAlCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT119&dq=force+theme+star+wars+music&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiduYry_vDMAhVl5YMKHcUADKwQ6AEIKTAC#v=onepage&q=force%20theme%20star%20wars%20music&f=false|title=The Ultimate Guide to Star Wars|last=Weinert-Kendt|first=Rob|publisher=Time Inc. Books|year=2015|isbn=9781618934802|chapter=Music of the Galaxy}}</ref>
===Religion and spirituality=== In his 1977 review of ''Star Wars'', [[Vincent Canby]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' called the Force "a mixture of what appears to be ESP and early Christian faith".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/library/film/052677wars.html|title=''Star Wars''—A Trip to a Far Galaxy That's Fun and Funny...|last=Canby|first=Vincent|date=May 26, 1977|work=[[The New York Times]]|authorlink=Vincent Canby|accessdate=May 23, 2016}}</ref> ''The Magic of Myth'' compares the sharp distinction between the good "light side" and evil "dark side" of the Force to [[Zoroastrianism]], which posits that "good and evil, like light and darkness, are contrary realities".<ref name="magicofmyth" /> The connectedness between the light and dark sides has been compared to the relationship between [[yin and yang]] in [[Taoism]],<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FfBJSfmRhm0C&pg=PT53|title=Religions Of Star Trek|last2=Cassidy|first2=William|last3=Schwartz|first3=Susan L.|date=2009|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=0786750227|last1=Kraemer|first1=Ross}}</ref> although the balance between yin and yang lacks the element of evil associated with the dark side.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fHgKDWAZ0SIC&pg=PA156|title=Sex, Politics, and Religion in Star Wars: An Anthology|last=Jamilla|first=Nick|date=2012|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=081088514X|pages=156–157|chapter=Chapter 12: Defining the Jedi Order|editor1-last=Brode|editor1-first=Douglas|editor2-last=Deyneka|editor2-first=Leah}}</ref> Taylor identifies other similarities between the Force and a [[Navajo]] prayer, [[prana]], and [[qi]].<ref name="taylor-59" /> It is a common plot device in ''[[jidaigeki]]'' films like ''[[The Hidden Fortress]]'' (1958), which inspired ''Star Wars'', for [[samurai]] who master qi to achieve astonishing feats of swordsmanship.<ref>[[#kaminski|Kaminski]], p. 76</ref> Taylor added that the lack of detail about the Force makes it "a religion for the secular age".<ref name="taylor-58" /> According to Jennifer Porter, professor of religious studies at the [[Memorial University of Newfoundland]], "the Force is a metaphor for godhood that resonates and inspires within [people] a deeper commitment to the godhood identified within their traditional faith".<ref name="taylor-59-60">[[#taylor|Taylor]], pp. 59–60</ref>
===Comparison to magic=== [[Paranormal]] abilities like the Force are a common device in science fiction,<ref name="Stratmann 249">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nYeQCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA249&dq=Using+Medicine+in+Science+Fiction:+The+SF+Writer%E2%80%99s+Guide+to+Human+Biology+Obi-Wan+Kenobi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjq9bu5g-rMAhXLFR4KHVtKAIEQ6AEIJjAA#v=onepage&q=Using%20Medicine%20in%20Science%20Fiction%3A%20The%20SF%20Writer%E2%80%99s%20Guide%20to%20Human%20Biology%20Obi-Wan%20Kenobi&f=false|title=Using Medicine in Science Fiction: The SF Writer's Guide to Human Biology|last=Stratmann|first=H. G.|date=2016|publisher=Springer International Publishing|isbn=978-3-319-16015-3|page=249|accessdate=May 20, 2016}}</ref> and the Force has been compared to the role [[Magic (paranormal)|magic]] plays in the [[fantasy]] genre.<ref name="Sherman 157">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=er6YCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA157&dq=Wizards:+The+Myths,+Legends,+%26+Lore+the+force+magic+the+jedi+wizards&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjmlN7yquXMAhWI7YMKHYPHD5gQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=Wizards%3A%20The%20Myths%2C%20Legends%2C%20%26%20Lore%20the%20force%20magic%20the%20jedi%20wizards&f=false|title=Wizards: The Myths, Legends, & Lore|last=Sherman|first=Aubrey|date=2014|publisher=Adams Media|isbn=9781440582882|page=157|accessdate=May 20, 2016}}</ref> The ''Star Wars'' films illustrate that characters not familiar with the particulars of the Force associate it with mysticism and magic, such as when an Imperial officer alludes to Darth Vader's "sorcerer's ways".<ref name="Sherman 157" /> Christina Flotmann distinguishes between the depiction of the Force in the ''Star Wars'' franchise and the depiction of magic in the ''[[Harry Potter]]'' fantasy series,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N7LJBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA5&dq=The+Mythical+Ambiguity+of+Star+Wars+And+Harry+Potter+Christina+Flotmann+Contents&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwim-aKTv-rMAhUQzGMKHWP0AZgQ6AEIHzAA#v=onepage&q=The%20Mythical%20Atrombiguity%20of%20Star%20Wars%20And%20Harry%20Potter%20Christina%20Flotmann%20Contents&f=false|title=Ambiguity in Star Wars And Harry Potter: A (Post) Structuralist Reading of Two Popular Myths|last=Flotmann|first=Christina|publisher=Transcript Verlag|year=2014|isbn=978-3-837-62148-8|pages=368|accessdate=May 21, 2016}}</ref> and she describes the Force as a spiritual energy.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N7LJBAAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Mythical+Ambiguity+of+Star+Wars+And+Harry+Potter+Christina+Flotmann&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiKmMqowurMAhVB_GMKHYfYBxgQ6AEIHzAA#v=onepage&q=%20spiritual%20energy&f=false|title=Ambiguity in Star Wars And Harry Potter|last=Flotmann|page=368|accessdate=May 21, 2016}}</ref>
Eric Charles points out that the television films ''[[Caravan of Courage: An Ewok Adventure]]'' (1984) and ''[[Ewoks: The Battle for Endor]]'' (1985), intended for children, are "fairy tales in a science fiction setting".<ref name="Charles">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=LV4Wdl13aqMC&pg=PA130&dq=Myth,+Media,+and+Culture+in+Star+Wars+ewok+adventures+fairytale&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj_nuWLqObMAhXBPCYKHXayA88Q6AEIJTAA#v=onepage&q=Myth%2C%20Media%2C%20and%20Culture%20in%20Star%20Wars%20ewok%20adventures%20fairytale&f=false|title=Myth, Media, and Culture in Star Wars: An Anthology|last=Charles|first=Eric|date=2012|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-810-88513-4|pages=129–131|chapter=The Jedi Network: ''Star Wars''{{'}} Portrayal and Inspirations on the Small Screen|editor-last2=Deyneka|editor-first2=Leah|editor-first1=Douglas|editor-last1=Brode|accessdate=May 20, 2016}}</ref> These films feature magic and other fairy tale motifs rather than the Force and science fiction [[Trope (literature)|tropes]].<ref name="Charles" /> Mark Clark said the ''Ewok Adventure'' films depict "sorcery" that is completely different from the Force powers depicted in the original and prequel ''Star Wars'' films.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Star Wars FAQ: Everything Left to Know About the Trilogy That Changed the Movies|last=Clark|first=Mark|publisher=Applause Theatre & Cinema Books|year=2015|isbn=9781480360181|chapter=26}}</ref> ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' said ''The Last Jedi'' depicts the Force "closer to the sorcery of fairy tales and medieval romance than it’s ever been".<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.avclub.com/part-kurosawa-part-wile-e-coyote-the-last-jedi-boldl-1821291545|title=Part Kurosawa, part Wile E. Coyote, The Last Jedi boldly rewires Star Wars' origins|last=Vishnevetsky|first=Ignatiy|date=December 15, 2017|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|access-date=April 2, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
===Scientific and parascientific perspectives=== Astrophysicist [[Jeanne Cavelos]] says in ''[[The Science of Star Wars (book)|The Science of Star Wars]]'' that the Force raises questions that scientists have long asked.<ref name="cavelos-177">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], p. 177</ref> She points out that the ancient Greeks explored the idea of a "[[Aether (classical element)|fifth element]]" that permeated and connected everything in the universe, and that [[Isaac Newton]] proposed that the human brain might be able to trigger waves in the [[Aether theories|ether]], giving humans psychic powers.<ref name="cavelos-179-180">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], pp. 179–180</ref> Cavelos's sources are mostly skeptical about a "real world" explanation for the Force, but they explore ideas in areas such as [[quantum physics]], [[parapsychology]], and the notion of science so advanced that it appears magical.<ref name="cavelos-178-179">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], pp. 178–179</ref> Explaining the Force is particularly difficult, Cavelos says, because "it does so many different things".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/science-of-star-wars-clone-wars/|title=The Science of Star Wars: The Clone Wars -- Q&A with Author Jeanne Cavelos|last=Hadhazy|first=Adam|date=August 11, 2008|website=[[Scientific American]]|publisher=[[Springer Nature]]|access-date=May 26, 2016}}</ref> Several scientists have said it is best not to try to explain how the Force works.<ref name="cavelos-179">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], p. 179</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cam.ac.uk/research/discussion/how-real-is-the-science-in-star-wars|title=How real is the science in Star Wars?|last=Yu|first=Karen|date=December 18, 2015|website=[[University of Cambridge]]|access-date=May 25, 2016|quote=...perhaps there are some wonders in Star Wars that we don’t need to explain.}}</ref>
Cavelos says the Force "suggests a universe quite different than the one we think we're living in", and that some unknown fields or particles might explain the Force.<ref name="cavelos-191-192">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], pp. 191–192</ref> Cavelos believes [[vacuum energy]] is one option to power physical Force feats,<ref name="cavelos-180">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], p. 180</ref> and she says a [[fifth force]] beyond the [[Fundamental interaction|four fundamental interactions]] might account for the Force.<ref name="cavelos-191">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], p. 191</ref> Flavio Fenton of the [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] School of Physics suggests a fifth force would carry two types of charge — one for the light side and one for the dark — and that each would be carried by its own particle.<ref name="gatech">{{Cite web|url=http://www.news.gatech.edu/features/science-star-wars|title=The Science of Star Wars|last=Maderer|first=Jason|publisher=[[Georgia Institute of Technology]]|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref> Nepomuk Otte, also from Georgia Tech, cautions that [[Newton's laws of motion|Newton's third law of motion]] says telekinesis would apply a force back on the Force-wielding character.<ref name="gatech" /> Force powers like [[precognition]] are challenging to explain because of the implied time travel of information, but Cavelos suggests [[tachyon]]s traveling [[Faster-than-light|faster than light]] might carry such information.<ref name="cavelos-188-189">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], pp. 188–189</ref> Cavelos explores the possibility of brain implants or sensors being used to detect users' intent and manipulate energy fields to control the Force.<ref name="cavelos-183-184">[[#sosw|Cavelos]], pp. 183–184</ref> [[Michio Kaku]] says Luke Skywalker's Jedi training on [[Dagobah]] might involve learning to control [[Electroencephalography|brain waves]], and Cavelos compares such discipline to contemporary patients learning to control [[Prosthesis|prosthetics]].<ref name="cavelos-183-184" />

web|url=https://nypost.com/2009/06/30/jedi-mind-trick-do-you-can/|title=Jedi Mind Trick Do You Can|last=Kaplan|first=Don|date=June 30, 2009|work=[[New York Post]]|access-date=May 25, 2016}}</ref>
''[[The New Republic]]'', [[Townhall]], ''[[The Atlantic]]'', and others have compared various political machinations to the "Jedi mind trick", a Force power used to undermine opponents' perceptions and willpower.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newrepublic.com/minutes/125959/donald-trumps-jedi-mind-trick-pledge-republican-party|first=Ryu|last=Spaeth|title= Donald Trump’s Jedi mind trick is his pledge to the Republican Party|publisher=[[Hamilton Fish V]]|work=[[The New Republic]]}}</ref><ref name="Townhall"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2013/12/the-war-on-terrors-jedi-mind-trick/282620/|title=The War on Terror's Jedi Mind Trick|last=Sanchez|first=Julian|date=December 23, 2013|work=[[The Atlantic]]|access-date=May 22, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-35256156|title=Obama's 'Jedi mind trick' and a revealing admission|last=Kay|first=Katty|publisher=BBC News|date=January 23, 2016|language=en-GB|access-date=May 22, 2016}}</ref>
Practitioners of [[Jediism]] pray to and express gratitude to the Force.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=PB57P_dOF7EC&oi=fnd&pg=PR11&dq=%22The+force%22+%22Star+Wars%22+%22Clone+Wars%22&ots=HlZMEfeIAa&sig=QKOImk7EsMyAYMnrIsEXocTlV-0#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Finding the Force of the Star Wars Franchise: Fans, Merchandise, & Critics|last=Kapell|first=Matthew|last2=Lawrence|first2=John Shelton|publisher=Peter Lang|year=2006|isbn=9780820463339|pages=107}}</ref> ''[[io9]]'' described a kind message to a fan from [[Mark Hamill]], who portrays Luke Skywalker, as an example of the light side of the Force.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://io9.gizmodo.com/mark-hamill-continues-to-justify-twitters-existence-1782032570|title=Mark Hamill Continues to Justify Twitter's Existence|last=Trendacosta|first=Katharine|date=June 15, 2016|website=[[io9]]|publisher=[[Gawker Media]]|access-date=June 16, 2016}}</ref>
=== Critical response === [[John Simon (critic)|John Simon]] wrote in his 1977 review of ''Star Wars'' for ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine: {{Quote|And then there is that distressing thing called the Force, which is ... Lucas's tribute to something beyond science: imagination, the soul, God in man ... It appears in various contradictory and finally nonsensical guises, a facile and perfunctory bow to metaphysics. I wish that Lucas had had the courage of his materialistic convictions, instead dragging in a sop to a spiritual force the main thrust of the movie so cheerfully ignores.<ref name="Simon">{{cite journal |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QuQCAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&dq=star%20wars&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q=star%20wars&f=false |first=John |last=Simon |authorlink=John Simon (critic) |title=Star Dust |journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |page=71 |date=June 20, 1977 |accessdate=May 23, 2016}}</ref><ref name="Lincoln">{{cite web |last=Lincoln |first=Kevin |title=Looking Back at ''New York''{{'s}} Critical 1977 Review of ''Star Wars''|url=http://www.vulture.com/2015/12/nymag-original-star-wars-review-1977.html# |publisher=[[Vulture.com]]|date=December 17, 2015 |accessdate=May 23, 2016}}</ref>}}
Critic Tim Robley compared the Force to the [[ruby slippers]] from ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' (1939), with both being entities that send the protagonist on a quest.<ref name="Robley">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/star-wars--a-new-hope/movies-influences-george-lucas/|title=10 films that influenced ''Star Wars''|last=Robey|first=Tim|date=November 24, 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group]]|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> In her 1980 ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' review of ''The Empire Strikes Back'', [[Judith Martin]] described the Force as "a mishmash of current cultic fashions without any base in ideas. It doesn't seem to be connected with ethics or a code of decent behavior, either."<ref>{{Cite web |first=Judith |last=Martin |authorlink=Judith Martin |date=May 23, 1980 |title=''The Empire Strikes Back'' |work=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/movies/review97/empirestrikesbackmartin.htm |accessdate=May 23, 2016}}</ref>
The introduction of midi-chlorians in ''The Phantom Menace'' was controversial, with Evan Narcisse of ''Time'' writing that the concept ruined ''Star Wars'' for him and a generation of fans because "the mechanisms of the Force became less spiritual and more scientific".<ref name="time" /> Film historian Daniel Dinello argued, "Anathema to ''Star Wars'' fanatics who thought they reduced the Force to a kind of viral infection, midi-chlorians provide a biological interface, the link between physical bodies and spiritual energy."<ref>{{Cite book|first=Daniel|last=Dinello|title=Technophobia!: Science Fiction Visions of Posthuman Technology|year=2005|publisher=University of Texas Press|location=Austin|page=211|isbn=0-292-70986-2}}</ref> Referring to "midi-chlorians" became a screenwriting shorthand for over-explaining a concept.<ref name="forgivegl">{{Cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/film/star-wars-the-force-awakens/george-lucas-movies-hate-defence/|title=Why it's time to stop hating George Lucas|last=Bell|first=Chris|date=December 16, 2015|website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|access-date=May 26, 2016}}</ref> Although Chris Taylor suggested fans want less detail, not more, in explaining the Force,<ref name="taylor-58" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/books/review-how-star-wars-conquered-the-universe-by-chris-taylor/2014/10/09/6cd5afa2-32bc-11e4-8f02-03c644b2d7d0_story.html|title=Review: ''How Star Wars Conquered the Universe'' by Chris Taylor|last=Musgrove|first=Mike|date=October 10, 2014|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=May 24, 2016}}</ref> the introduction of midi-chlorians provided depth to the franchise and fomented engagement among fans and franchise writers.<ref name="forgivegl" /> Religion expert [[John D. Caputo]] writes, "In the 'Gospel according to Lucas' a world is conjured up in which the intractable oppositions that have tormented religious thinkers for centuries are reconciled ... The gifts that the Jedi masters enjoy have a perfectly plausible scientific basis, even if its ways are mysterious".<ref>{{Cite book|title=On Religion|last=Caputo|first=John D.|publisher=Routledge|year=2001|isbn=0-415-23332-1|location=London|page=87}}</ref>
Characters' faith in the Force reinforces the ''Rogue One''{{'}}s message of hope.<ref name="timerogueone">{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4604797/rogue-one-star-wars-force-jedi-religion/|title=Everything You Need to Know About the Force in Rogue One|first=Megan|last=McCluskey|date=December 16, 2016|accessdate=May 24, 2017|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=Time Inc.}}</ref> ''The A.V. Club'' said Rian Johnson's depiction of the Force in ''The Last Jedi'' goes "beyond George Lucas’ original transcendental concept".<ref name=":0" /> ''[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]'' said Johnson's film "democratize[s] the Force", depicting Force sensitivity in characters from outside a "Force-sensitive lineage" and suggesting that the Force can be used by anyone.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/platform/amp/2017/12/30/16791054/star-wars-the-last-jedi-force-franchise-disney-lucasfilm-rian-johnson|title=Star Wars: The Last Jedi opens up the Force, which makes business sense for Disney - Polygon|last=Sarkar|first=Samit|date=December 30, 2017|website=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|language=en|access-date=April 2, 2018}}</ref>
=== "May the Force be with you" === {{Redirect|May the Force be with you|other uses|}} Several ''Star Wars'' characters say "May the Force be with you" (or derivatives of it) and the expression has become a popular [[catchphrase]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gomez|first1=Rolando|title=Socially Smart: Twitter Plus Facebook, Marketing Multipliers And Brand Boosters|publisher=BookBaby|isbn=9781626754751|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=wJddDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT18#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=28 April 2017|language=en}}</ref> In 2005, "May the Force be with you" was chosen as number 8 on the [[American Film Institute]]'s [[AFI's 100 Years... 100 Movie Quotes|100 Years... 100 Movie Quotes]] list.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/100years/quotes.aspx|title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes|author=[[American Film Institute]]|accessdate=May 25, 2016|year=2005}}</ref> May 4 is [[Star Wars Day]], taken from the [[pun]] "May the Fourth be with you".<ref>{{citation|title='Star Wars' Day: May The 4th Be With You|date=May 4, 2010|url=http://www.myfoxchattanooga.com/dpps/entertainment/star-wars-day-may-the-4th-be-with-you-dpgoha-20100504-fc_7371587|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100508193201/http://www.myfoxchattanooga.com/dpps/entertainment/star-wars-day-may-the-4th-be-with-you-dpgoha-20100504-fc_7371587|deadurl=yes|publisher=My Fox Chattanooga|archivedate=May 8, 2010}}.</ref> The expression was intentionally similar to the Christian ''[[dominus vobiscum]]'', "the Lord be with you".<ref name="taylor-60">[[#taylor|Taylor]], p. 60</ref>
President [[Ronald Reagan]] in 1985 said "the Force is with us", referring to the [[United States]], to create the [[Strategic Defense Initiative]] to protect against [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Intercontinental ballistic missile|ballistic missiles]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1985-03-30/news/8501170975_1_aggressive-civilian-space-agenda-star-wars-national-space-club|title='The Force Is With Us,' Reagan Says|last=de Lama|first=George|date=March 30, 1985|website=[[The Chicago Tribune]]|access-date=June 2, 2016}}</ref> Some weeks earlier, Reagan had compared the [[Soviet Union|Soviets]] to the [[Galactic Empire (Star Wars)|Galactic Empire]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/05/04/politics/flashback-friday-reagan-star-wars-speech/index.html|title=#FBF: Ronald Reagan and Star Wars|last=Williams|first=Brenna|date=May 4, 2018|work=[[CNN]]|access-date=May 4, 2018|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]}}</ref> ''The Gospel According to Star Wars'' asserts that Reagan's invocation of the Force <nowiki/>{{Quote|text=was actually perverting [''Star Wars'']'s<!--originally "SW"--> "self-dispossessing" (or other-focused) ethos. [The]<!--originally ANH, an initialism not used elsewhere in the article, nor is even the title "A New Hope"--> blessing "May the Force be with you" is the expression of a hope ''for others'' ("May the Force be ''with you''"), not ''for ourselves'' as with Reagan ("The Force is with ''us''"). Moreover, the [''Star Wars'']<!--originally "SW"--> blessing is precisely a request for ''hope'' for others ("''May'' the Force be with you"), whereas Reagan's claim sounds like a ''possessive'' assertion ("The Force ''is'' with us").<ref>{{cite book|title=The Gospel According to Star Wars: Faith, Hope, and the Force|first=John C.|last=McDowell|publisher=[[Westminster John Knox]]|year=2007|page=26|isbn=9781611644258}}</ref><!--FYI, emphasis/italics are from the original source-->}}

(formerly 2005) | founder = | defunct = | location_city = [[Seoul]] | location_country = [[South Korea]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Sangwon Chung ([[CEO]]) | industry = [[Online Games]] | products = | production = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = Studio One
Studio NT | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = }} '''Thingsoft''' ({{lang-ko|띵소프트}}) is an online game development company in South Korea. Its headquarters is in Seoul, South Korea. ==History== Thingsoft was originally established in 2005 with funding from [[Neowiz]], a large South Korean online game publisher. [[Neowiz]] fully acquired Thingsoft in 2006 following the successful launch of Thingsoft's first commercial product, FIFA Online. The acquisition integrated Thingsoft into the [[Neowiz]] as an internal development studio. In 2007, [[Neowiz]] split into several smaller companies, and Thingsoft was officially changed to [[Neowiz Games]] Development Studio. Thingsoft was responsible for the development of several online games including FIFA Online, [[FIFA Online 2]], the NBA Street Online series, [[Battlefield Online]], [[Warlord]], Xogu Pigu, Sashinmu, and Perfect KO. [[FIFA Online 2]] proved especially successful in South Korea and garnered over 180,000 [[concurrent user]]s in 2006[http://article.joins.com/article/article.asp?ctg=12&Total_ID=2478832 Football finals kickoff online for FIFA game] and over 220,000 concurrent users in 2010.[http://www.asiamog.com/?p=183 FIFA Online 2 Korea cracks 220K Concurrent Users] In 2010, the founders of Thingsoft and core developers from [[FIFA Online 2]] and Project GG left [[Neowiz Games]] to start a new independent online development company. The new company acquired the rights to the trademark and is once again known as Thingsoft.{{ko icon}} [http://www.thisisgame.com/board/view.php?id=397178&category=103 Interview - Sangwon Chung, CEO of Thingsoft] ==Divisions== ===Studio One=== Studio One consists of core members from the [[FIFA Online 2]] development team. Studio One focuses on developing casual online games and is currently developing [[social network game]]s.{{ko icon}} [http://www.dt.co.kr/contents.html?article_no=2010080602011231749002 Interview - Jae Kim, Head of Studio One, Thingsoft] Studio One has developed its own online game engine capable of supporting both casual [[MMO game]]s and [[social network game]]s. Studio One's first [[social network game]], "[[Wonder Cruise]]", launched on Facebook in December 2011.[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/nexon-docks-ss-wonder-cruise-224900586.html Nexon Docks SS Wonder Cruise on Facebook Today] [[Wonder Cruise]] is a cruise simulation game where users are tasked with running their own luxury cruise liner.[http://www.insidesocialgames.com/2011/12/09/nexon-christens-wonder-cruise-on-facebook/ Nexon Christens Wonder Cruise on Facebook] ===Studio NT=== Studio NT consists of core members from the Project GG development team. Studio NT is developing a new [[MMORPG]], codenamed "Project NT", utilizing their proprietary 3D engine using an enhanced animation system. ===Project NT=== Project NT is an [[MMORPG]] that uses cell animation in a Japanese anime style. The game utilizes a self-developed engine that the developers say will allow players to use various [[sandbox game|sandbox]] features such as building a town and play-writing cutscenes. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Entertainment software]] [[Category:Online games]]

'''''Violet''''' is a work of [[interactive fiction]] by American author [[Jeremy Freese]].<ref name="jayaward" /> It is a one-room puzzle game.<ref name="jayaward" /> It took first place in the 2008 The protagonist of ''Violet'' is a graduate student trying to write 1,000 words for his dissertation.<ref name="avclub">{{cite web | url = http://www.avclub.com/articles/violet-and-everybody-dies,17091/ | title = Violet and Everybody Dies | date = 2008-12-22 | accessdate = 2009-01-17 | first = Christ | last = Dahlen | work = [[The A.V. Club]] | publisher = [[The Onion|Onion Inc]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.avclub.com%2Farticles%2Fviolet-and-everybody-dies%2C17091%2F&date=2009-01-17 | archivedate = 2009-01-17 }}</ref> The protagonist's girlfriend, Violet, threatens to leave otherwise.<ref name="avclub" /><ref name="jayisgames">{{cite web | url = http://jayisgames.com/archives/2008/11/violet.php | title = Violet | accessdate = 2009-01-17 | date = 2008-11-18 | last = Short | first = Emily | authorlink = Emily Short | work = [[Jay Is Games]] | publisher = [[Jay Is Games]] | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fjayisgames.com%2Farchives%2F2008%2F11%2Fviolet.php&date=2009-01-17 | archivedate = 2009-01-17 }}</ref> The protagonist faces a stream of distractions,<ref name="avclub" /> including a window with a view of the campus, and a computer with access to [[blog]]s and [[webcomic]]s.<ref name="jayisgames" /> In the course of the game, the protagonist must "reconsider—and risk wrecking—" his career and relationship.<ref name="avclub" />
A reviewer for ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' described the puzzles as "smart but logical" and "fit[ting] thematically into the story."<ref name="avclub" /> The reviewer also called out the ability to disable "'heteronormativity,' so you can play as Violet’s girlfriend" as something that makes the game "Worth playing for".<ref name="avclub" /> A second review also observes this option, noting that at least one puzzle changes based on the choice.<ref name="jayisgames" />
A writer for [[Jay Is Games]] called out ''Violet'' for "succeed[ing] in the difficult task of capturing the intricacies of a dynamic relationship."<ref name="jayaward" /> The writer also praised the game for succeeding at engaging the player at "the core emotional level", again noting how difficult this is.<ref name="jayaward" /> [[Emily Short]], in a review on Jay Is Games, noted the strength of the implementation, pointing to the breadth of "interesting responses even to silly or unexpected actions."<ref name="jayisgames" /> Short felt that the characters were "seemingly-real" and "their problem is plausible and serious."<ref name="jayisgames" />
